The first morning I saw her I was late, which was already a sign that my day would lean sideways. Bells from the cathedral came down the hill and folded over the roofs; they always do that in St Albans, as if time is a soft thing that can be laid gently on brick and slate. I left my house on Clarence Road with my scarf half-knotted and my casefile under my arm. The rain had decided to be thin and indecisive, like an argument you could walk away from without saying anything that couldn’t be unsaid.

Number 12 had been empty for two months. The landlord had come and gone in a white van that smelled faintly, somehow, of turpentine whenever he left the door open. And now there were boxes stacked like pale teeth behind the thin curtains, and the front garden—which could have been handsome, if anyone tried—was newly raked. There she was, kneeling at the step with a hammer in one hand, coaxing the letterbox back to its hinges. I slowed down before I knew I was slowing down.

She had tied her hair up with a faded scarf, the kind with little stars picked into the weave. It made the dark of her hair look deliberate, arranged. Not pretty exactly, that’s too small a word, but assembled in such a way you could believe the world had stopped for a second to get a better look. Her coat was paint-splattered, a green that had been green for some time and then had allowed itself to become a paler thing.

“Excuse me,” she said without looking up, and the hammer skipped once on the brass. “Do you live next door?”

I suppose I nodded, or said yes, or smiled. Something adequate must have happened between us because she held out two envelopes with the corner of one thumb and said, “Postman is an anarchist. These say ten but may as well have been in my shoe.”

I took them. I do not remember the texture of the paper. This annoys me. I am a lawyer. I notice things. I’m supposed to.

“Welcome to the street,” I said, which was the polite thing. “It’s quiet. Except Saturdays. And sometimes Thursdays. There’s a trumpet player somewhere who has discovered Thursdays.”

She smiled, and one side of her mouth decided to go higher than the other, as if the whole of her face was rehearsing asymmetries. “Iris,” she said.

Her name fell into me like a coin into a fountain, unsettling the water under the water.

“Bret,” I said. “I— I’m on my way to court.” I waved the casefile as if it were a passport.

“To put the trumpet player in prison?”

“Sadly the law is ambiguous on brass.”

She laughed and tucked a strand of hair behind her ear with the hand that wasn’t holding the hammer. There was a dark smear on her thumb that could have been ink or could have been something else. I have replayed that tiny gesture more times than I’d care to tell you, and in each replay the smear becomes something new.

“Good luck,” Iris said, tapping the letterbox gently, and I walked away.

On the train I stood because St Albans City at half past eight is a particular chaos, and the men who fold their newspapers into murderous little squares do not relish sharing. I rehearsed opening statements in my head, but my mind—stupid, disloyal mind—kept insisting on that scarf, those stars it borrowed, and the way her mouth made a decision by itself. I remembered suddenly that Saint Alban had sheltered a stranger and then put on his hood to be taken in the stranger’s place. It is a story we tell tourists, and ourselves, to make our roads make sense.

“You okay?” Priya asked when I got to the office, because she always knows when my mind has gained a fever that my hands deny.

“I am making a list,” I said, pulling off my coat. “Of the crimes for which there ought to be swift and terrible justice. Trumpet playing is number one.”

She raised an eyebrow. “Number two?”

“Bananas on toast. People who chew pens. People who borrow biros and then press down so hard you can feel the ghosts of their signatures on paper three.”

“Bret,” she said, her voice making my name into a caution and an invitation. “What’s number four?”

“Moving in next door with a hammer,” I said, and immediately wished I hadn’t, because Priya has a face that is all mirror. She catches you looking and gives you back to yourself in a cleaner frame.

She smiled. “Glad to see the diligent people of Clarence Road continue to perform emergency repairs between raindrops.”

“It’s— it’s nothing,” I said. Stupidity number one of the day: saying something is nothing. Of course it was something. Even when it is nothing, it is something. We spend our lives in the porous between.

“Good,” Priya said, and pressed a mug into my hand that had the law’s scales on it, one chipped slightly at the bottom, making the scales tilt. “Because you’re in chambers at ten, and Dawson is in a mood.”

Dawson, senior partner at Foster & Vale, liked to think of himself as the last gentleman. He wore ties as if they had been invented for him. He had once told me, earnestly, that the law is a chorus and we are its voices. On bad days he told me that the law is a blade and we sharpen it on human behavior. He was in a mood. But that’s later. THIS is earlier.

The morning court case was not glamorous. It rarely is, like most things that keep the world from tilting into ditch. Boundary disputes are a kind of silent warfare, and the war that day was two hedges wide. Mr. Pemberton had a chain-link fence and a righteous belief in his tape measure. Mrs. Elliot had a rosebush that had been there longer than her children, and not much patience left for the precise placement of pegs. I spoke, then Priya spoke, then a man with a checkered tie spoke. We introduced photographs that were mostly hedge. The judge was exquisitely bored, an art form in itself.

I watched how the participants positioned themselves. Crossed arms. Thumbs hidden, thumbs visible. Eyes sliding to the door. And I thought of letterboxes being reattached, and the small sound a hammer makes when it has nearly figured out how to be useful again.

At lunch I walked down to the cathedral because I do that sometimes. There is a coolness under the stones that exists even in October, a long, old calm like a reliable friend. The martyrs, cut into panels, look down with their preset expressions, and my footsteps in that nave are always unplaceable; I hear myself coming. There is a glass window that looks like falling. There is a carved capital where regular leaves curl around a face that looks surprised to be found. A child ran through the chairs and laughed. I wanted to tell him to keep that laugh clean, that one day he would need it; I wanted to say, Don’t let them parcel your laugh into documents and disclaimers.

It took me a week to ask, after that first morning, and even then it wasn’t asking. It was rain. Rain has manners in this city; it makes decisions gently. The pavement shone without entirely committing to being wet. The sky hung at a reasonable height. On my step there was a parcel in beige paper that might as well have belonged to the century before ours. It had my name without my title, as if I were not an adult yet, only a person between brackets. The return address was a shop on Holywell Hill I didn’t know. It contained three pale candles and a note that said, simply, “For a time that decides to behave.” There was no name.

So I knocked on Iris’s door because who else would know what to do with time. It took longer than I expected for her to open, and by the time she did, in bare feet and with one eyebrow arched, I had run through an impressive array of excuses in my head: I was the local parcel redistribution hub; I was a candle inspector; I was newly religious.

“Do you know what this is?” I asked, holding out the candles as if they might explode.

“Hello again to you too,” she said, and stepped back so I could see the hallway behind her. It was in demobilized boxes, those slim cardboard coffins that keep histories in polite heaps. “Come in.”

The air inside number 12 smelled like dust that has learned a new purpose. It smelled like the gentle surrender of wood. A plant waited on a windowsill the way a question waits in a room.

“I’ve bought three things and borrowed twenty,” Iris said, taking the candles and standing them on an empty mantel as if arranging chess pieces. “Do you drink tea, or are you one of those men who drink gin when the light hits the first brick?”

“I drink tea,” I said. “Often as revenge.”

She laughed, and I noticed there were charcoal lines on the back of her hand, faint rings tracing up towards the wrist as if she had tried on bracelets and then forgotten to wash them off. She followed my gaze and rubbed at them absentmindedly, which made them smudge and soften. “Work,” she said.

“What do you do?”

“I paint mostly. And some days I decide to stop painting and do something else and then I pretend that is my life now. It doesn’t always work. A while I did sound. Not music.” She tilted her head, listening to a nearby siren that stitched the air through Hatfield Road. “Sound like you listen to the shape of a room and then you make it different.”

“The shape of a room is important,” I said. “I am suddenly alert to the shape of rooms.”

“It is, Bret-not-a-title,” she said, looking at the note I had brought in with the candles. “Would you like a ridiculous biscuit? I have the ones that pretend to be digestives but are actually sugar.”

I took a biscuit mostly because it would be impolite not to, and partly because there is a kind of hunger that’s not about food at all, and sometimes you have to give it something to hold in its fist.

“What’s your work?” she asked, sitting on the floor like a person who prefers the first level of things. There was a micro-scar at the corner of her thumb that shone. The room rustled like a coat dropped on a chair.

“Law,” I said, and her face made that tiny adjustment people’s faces make. “I know. It is not like the shows. The parts that are like the shows are the parts you should worry about.”

“Oh I don’t watch the shows,” she said. “I listen to people argue in supermarkets and decide who would win in case law. It’s more fun.”

“I represent hedges,” I said, and told her about Mr. Pemberton and Mrs. Elliot in a voice that made it sound nicer than it was. She laughed when she should. Then she told me about painting the river near Verulamium Park too fast, how she had to let the geese be smears because that day they refused to behave like geese. Her voice had a way of patting its children, a contained tenderness that did not spill unless she allowed it.

“Thank you for the candles,” I said when I remembered the manners I had put in my pocket. “I’ll save them for when time goes crooked.”

“Do,” she said. “I think time is like a poorly trained dog. It needs to be told what to fetch.”

“Does it know how to drop it?”

“If you trade it for something good. A walk. An apple. A confession.”

“Do you collect confessions?” I asked, and she smiled like someone who has been asked the right question by accident. She did not answer me then, but moved to the window and wiped a circle on the glass with the cuff of her sleeve.

“You can see the cathedral from here in winter,” she said. “When the trees get shy. I like it. The way the city can’t help looking at itself.”

We stood like that for a minute, my mug cooling, her sock a little damp where she had stepped into a quick puddle on the kitchen tile. The doorbell startled us both. She went and came back with a small package carefully wrapped in brown paper and string, like something that arrived by mistake from a different story about a different century. She didn’t open it immediately, and I wanted to ask her what it was, as if that would be a normal thing for a neighbor to do.

“I should let you get back to your life,” I said, because you are supposed to leave before the welcome’s elastic snaps.

She walked me to the door and, in that small space between hallway and weather, she looked as if she would say something that would scoop me a little closer, but then didn’t.

After that there were small things. The rain went away and returned as if it had forgotten its keys. My mother phoned me on Sundays and asked me if I was eating, which is a code mothers use to ask if you are lonely. Kit at work, who has a face like bread—plain and good and necessary—brought in a Tupperware of something he called lasagna but which had not so much layered as tumbled. Priya won a small case against a large man and smiled in a way that made you believe in justice again for a few hours. I bought a new pen and wrote my name with it too many times on a spare sheet because the first mark of ink is a ceremony if you let it be.

Sometimes, coming home, I would hear Iris singing behind her door, but never the whole of a song; only the part that understood what it was for. Sometimes an older woman came to see her, carrying a shopping bag full of lemons and herbs. They would talk on the step for a while and then one of them would laugh quietly, and the other would correct that laugh gently, as if not wanting to wake anyone. I never learned her name.

When the weather grew cooler she hung three small canvases on the wall opposite her couch and then decided she didn’t like them and turned them to face the plaster. This made the room look like it was being punished, and I had to resist an impulse to knock again and ask the paintings what they had done.

I bring you these things not to pad the tale but because if you don’t have the small things, you don’t have the big thing either. I have learned this both by watching the law work and by watching it not.

We built a conversation across our shared fence, in increments. She would lean over to pull a weed out from between the paving stones and say, “Is this a weed?” And I would say, “Everything is a weed if you give it a different name.” I’d bring in the bin and she would stand on her step and ask, “Does the bin always do that? Sulk?” We spoke about the fox who lived under the car on the corner and how he looked like a gentleman who had decided to be wild. We spoke about the crows and how they patrolled the streets as if we were the guests. Sometimes we didn’t speak; we stretched silence between us like a clean sheet and let the air straighten it.

Once, I was balancing a bag of potatoes and a disaster of oranges in my arms and the bottom of the bag parted company with the rest of the bag on my path. The oranges rolled, a jail break. Iris stepped out and caught two with the kind of reflex that makes you think of goalkeepers and doctors.

“Gravity likes me,” she said, handing them back. “Or hates me. We’re in a long-distance relationship.”

“Thank you,” I said, bending and scooping and laughing more than the moment deserved, because laughter is a solvent and I needed something to pour over the day. She handed me the last orange and that was when I saw the inside of her wrist carefully inked with a pencil line, very fine, that traced from the base of her palm to the thin bones like a road on a map. She saw me see it.

“It’s for later,” she said quietly. “I draw them first to see if they belong. Sometimes they don’t.”

“A sketch for a—” I said, and stopped because I did not want to be the kind of man who names things that are not his.

“For a thing,” she said, and turned her hand so the rain could erase it more quickly.

“Do you— do you have many?” I ask her, and immediately felt foolish because my skin was a landscape of precisely nothing, save a scar from a bicycle accident when I was nine and a faint ghost of a bee sting I still insist I remember.

“Some,” she said. “Mostly hidden. It feels... like carrying a story on the outside for once.”

“That sounds right,” I said, because it did. The law is a way of carrying a story on the outside of your head until someone agrees with you.

We met in the grocery on Victoria Street and pretended to be surprised. We met on the Alban Way and pretended not to be winded. We met under the same awning during a sudden, clean rain that lasted exactly three minutes, and we did not pretend anything. We shared the weather like a secret.

“Do you ever feel,” she said one Thursday when the trumpet player was briefly merciful, “like your name is a coat someone else bought for you?”

“Only all the time,” I said.

She twitched her mouth in that one-sided way. “My mother wanted to call me Iris because she liked the idea of seeing,” she said. “My father told her she liked the idea of drinking.”

“And?”

“She did both,” Iris said, and then laughed in a way that said this wasn’t a joke but we were allowed to place it in the shelf where jokes live.

We told each other our small facts. I told her how my father taught me to fix a leaky tap in a kitchen that is no longer a kitchen and how the sound of a slow drip can still hijack my whole chest. She told me about a job she had in a shop that sold only lights, and the day the lights all went out in a storm, and how customers came in anyway to stand among the dark lamps as if they were in a forest that had decided to sit down. I told her how, when I was nine, my schoolteacher Mrs. Marchant sent home a note I kept folded in a book for years, about how neat my handwriting was. She told me how she once gave a man a painting in exchange for a winter coat and never regretted that currency.

“Does the law move you?” she asked me one evening when the sky folded itself into a deeper blue and stayed, like a curtain that had learned manners.

“Not as much as the people inside it do,” I said, and meant several things at once. I am always meaning several things at once. It is a curse of people who have learned to speak through drafts.

“The river moved me today,” she said from her step. “It decided to be metal in the morning and cloth by afternoon. I would like to be as unapologetic as a river when I grow up.”

“Me too,” I said. “I’ll meet you there.”

That week I kept noticing marks. On bus shelters. On people’s arms. On the side of the fishmonger’s van where someone had written love with one of the letters scratched out so you had to complete it with your mind. On the floor at court where tape marks drew borders for chairs that could not remember where to stand. The city seemed to be labeling itself for me, and I wasn’t sure whether to be comforted or suspected. Every phone call, every file, I wanted to write a small note in the margin and say, Look here, a sign. Look here, a thing that means more than it means.

It was almost November when Priya asked me to come to a gallery on a back street near the Clock Tower where someone she knew had hung photographs of windows. “You’ll hate it,” she said happily. “But in a way you’ll enjoy hating it.”

“I have a neighbor,” I said, because we do this, we introduce new people into our old sentences.

“You do,” she said, with interest but not surprise. “Do you like this neighbor?”

I sifted through shapes of words, like coins in the pocket of someone else’s trousers. “I like how she makes me notice.”

“Dangerous,” Priya said. “Noticing leads to action. Or terrible poetry.”

We went anyway, and my suit felt wrong among all that art. The photographs were what she had said they would be: windows, neat in a grid, each with a slight variation, a plant or a curtain or a face you could not be sure you really saw. I stood there and did my duty of standing and thinking empathetic thoughts about detail. Iris arrived ten minutes in. She had changed her scarf; this one had little white birds along the edge that looked like commas that had learned to fly. She kissed me on the cheek like we had been doing it for years. “You hate it?” she asked, and I said, “Yes,” and she said, “Good.”

We walked out and down past a pub that was never sure what it was called and a charity shop that had more chairs than anyone could reasonably need. We went into a coffee place where the staff had names like Arlo and Kit and Thea, and they used mint in ways that made me distrust mint. We sat. She drew at the edge of a paper napkin, small arcs that intersected and then turned into something else. She did not notice she was doing it. The ink stained her index finger like a small surrender.

“Tell me what case you’re carrying in your pocket like a stone,” she said, because by then she had learned me.

“A girl,” I said. “Young. Sixteen. She took her mother’s car and went to Southend and then didn’t go back home exactly, and now everyone is trying to decide if she has done something wrong or just done something.”

“And?”

“She has done something,” I said. “Things are not always a crime when adults feel hurt. But we’re good at labelling them that way, because it’s easier to make a person a file than to make them a situation.”

Iris looked at me with a seriousness that held my face still. “Do you think I’m a situation?” she asked, and all the ordinary noise of the coffee shop bled into a single held note.

“Yes,” I said, because lying is a talent of mine that I decided not to use right then. “But I mean that as a compliment. A situation means there is time involved.”

“I like time,” she said, and then, without seeming to move at all, her hand was on my wrist, light, like the way a moth would be if a moth had decided to be gentle. She smiled and then didn’t.

I walked home that evening and the leaves had turned the color of tea when you forget the bag. I wanted to run, not because anything was chasing me, but because sometimes your bones want to arrive before your skin does. Iris was not home. A note on her door said, Back in an hour, with a drawing of a small fish in the corner, smiling like someone who knows better than to smile.

I put the kettle on. I sat at my table, which is not really mine, which belonged to my father for a long time and has the marks to prove it, and then belonged to a man called Tom who went to Spain with someone he met on the train, and was given to me as a kindness. I took out a sheet of paper and wrote, Dear Iris, and then stopped, because where do you put the rest of the sentence. I leaned my head against the cool glass of my back door and watched the fox take his route between compost bins like a commuter with better posture.

I couldn’t tell when I decided to love her. That’s not false modesty. Some decisions are a clean click. Others are a vandalism of will, unreadable until afterwards. It might have been when I first saw her with the hammer, making repairs to her world in the rain, because I have always liked people who make repairs. It might have been in the coffee shop, when her hand held me like a promise she didn’t have to redeem. It might have been when she told me about the winter coat, and navigated generosity with a map that felt known to my bones. It might have been the evening she stood in her doorway and said, “Do you wish the law was sometimes a person so you could forgive it?” and I laughed then because I wanted to kiss her.

In the morning I woke early and walked down to Verulamium Park. The water made that practicing-violins sound it makes when it tries to get your name right. Children in small uniforms marched in pairs. A woman threw bread at a loaf of ducks who had no intention of being polite about it. I thought about the fact that some of my happiest moments in recent months had happened within ten meters of a fence.

When I came back she was on her step, sitting cross-legged with a small mirror propped inside the door. She held a black pen—the kind with a precise, aggressive nib—and drew a line along the outer edge of her forearm, slow, like someone putting a road where there had never been one. She did not look up when I approached, and this seemed to me, absurdly, like a kind of trust. At the edge of the line she paused and glanced over, and the glance did everything a conversation attempts in paragraphs.

“Morning,” she said. “Do you ever feel like drawing on yourself to know where you are?”

“All the time,” I said, and then caught myself and turned that admission into a shrug. “I write on case files instead.”

“Useful,” she said, returning to the mirror, and I stood there for a moment, feeling my life press its face to the window and exhale.

You will think I forget other people existed, but I assure you they still did. The firm continued to be exactly itself. Dawson came into a meeting with a coat that knew it was expensive and a manner that had tested well in focus groups. He asked me to draft a letter to a client whose money had gone missing the way sometimes money takes a walk on a hot day. Priya told me she had dreamed of her grandmother folding sheets in an endless hotel that had no rooms. The trumpet played on Thursday like a small civil war and the crows voted with their wings to side with whoever paid attention.

It was late Friday when Iris knocked on my door for the first time. I had been halfway through a proper dinner and twenty-eight percent of the way through a sad one. I opened to find her with rain on her curls and a look like a petition.

“Electricity died,” she said. “It tried for a while to be both off and on and then decided to commit. I’m not frightened,” she added quickly, and then rolled her eyes at herself \— as if the word frightened was a dress that did not fit. “But it will be a while and my room looks like a shrug. Could I exist near you for a while?”

“Of course,” I said, which was easier to say than the other thing I was considering saying, which was Stay, but no one belongs to anyone and I am trying to be good at that. I made tea with the ceremony I make tea with when someone watches me. Iris sat at my table and curled the sleeve of her coin-colored jumper over her hands, and I found I was talking for both of us, because sometimes you have to pour words into the room so it doesn’t feel like the roof will come down. I told her about the first case I lost, and how I went home and ironed my shirts like I was punishing cotton. She told me about a dog she once found in Wales, temporary and soft, who followed her for a day and then made its own decision about belonging.

When it was time for her to go, she stood in my hall and we looked at our shoes like traitors. I saw, briefly, a pattern on her collarbone, ink or shadow or imagination, a geometry that implied decision. She saw me see, and the room leaned a bit.

“I’m marking again,” she said, almost apologetically. “I don’t know if I’ll keep it. There’s a shop down near London Road I go to sometimes, to ask questions. Perpetual Ink. Terrible name.”

“Perpetual,” I said, as if trying the word for weather. “Where does the name stop being a promise and become a threat?”

She smiled in the way that meant she liked the question. “I suppose we all decide that line at different times,” she said. “It’s a good thing the world is mostly indecisive.”

We said goodnight in the manner of people who have practiced alone and now find real circumstances harder. I closed my door and leaned my head against it and laughed softly like someone who has just tasted something they did not know they had been hungry for.

By then I had begun to keep a little notebook, a cheap one you can buy at the station. I told myself it was for work and then we both knew it was not. I wrote down groundless things that felt like ground. The time the bells rang not at the hour but some strange time in between and I swore the birds shifted by an invisible command. The way Mrs. Pell, who runs the shop at the corner, says my name like a question and then immediately answers it herself. The way my own name looks when written quickly, how the letters lean towards each other like conspirators. Iris’s lines on her skin. Iris’s hand holding a spoon. Iris’s anger when the man on the bus callously folded his newspaper and hit a woman’s shoulder with it and did not apologize. I had not known anger could look beautiful and I do not know if I approve of that.

You will ask me what I wanted. We are always asking ourselves that quietly in the backs of rooms while someone tells a story and arrives at the part where the wanting is the point. I wanted what I always want: to move across a room without the room changing itself to suit or to punish me. To sit with a person without parts of me turning their faces to the wall because they do not wish to be seen. To be looked at by a person who knows where my edges are and does not try to move them with their hands. To drink tea that does not cool quickly. To sleep without the night asking me for identification. To read a book and not disassemble it while I’m reading it, because not everything is work. To have the law in the room but sitting softly on the floor, not in my lap.

In December the market put up its lights and the stalls sold cinnamon and somehow that smell became the air for three weeks. I bought Iris a book because I am dull that way, but the book was illustrations of medieval animals that have never existed, and I wrote in the front: For when you need a creature that cannot be categorized. She opened it and ran her finger over a drawing of a hare with antlers, and then shut it quickly as if she were worried the hare would leave.

“For you,” she said, and handed me a fountain pen in a soft, severe case. “I watched a video of a man in Japan making it and I knew you would be unbearable with it.”

“I will,” I said, and then, in an act of uncharacteristic bravery, I took the lid off and wrote her name on the top page of my notebook so deliberately that my hand trembled.

We stood on the pavement, two people with small, expensive objects, snow plotting quietly above us without following through. I wanted to kiss the corner of her mouth, where decisions seemed to be made. I wanted to do it in front of the whole of Clarence Road and the fox and Mrs. Pell and the trumpet player. I did not. I do not know if that was courage or cowardice. The line between wind and weather is an argument the sky gets to win.

There was a night, late, when I woke from a dream where my father was teaching me again how to fix a leak and I was breaking everything I touched. The house made the night noises it keeps in a cupboard. I went to the window and saw a light on in Iris’s front room, a warm hold of light, and a moving shape, her. She was pacing, not in distress exactly, but like someone measuring the room to find its heart. She raised her arms and let them fall, repeated it three times, then stood very still. I stood at my pane of glass like a child at a museum, and then felt ashamed of the tiny distance. I made tea I didn’t drink and considered sending her a message I didn’t send. There is a way to love that feels like you are keeping watch, and a way to love that feels like you are standing guard against yourself.

The next day she knocked and said, “I need a witness.”

“I have only the law,” I said, trying to make a joke as a shield.

“Good,” she said. “I’m going to have a show. Small. Here. In the house. People in rooms looking at things on walls and pretending the rooms don’t matter. You’ll pretend with them. But I need you to look before they do, so the walls know they are going to be looked at.”

I nodded. I did not understand the job but I was ready to be asked. She moved through her rooms with the careful decisiveness of a sculptor of air. The canvases were new to me, and not. A river that refused to be only water; a forest that you could feel breathing. A window the exact blue the evening decides to be when it is not yet ready for black. A body—hers?—only partial, a collarbone that made me want to forgive everything. She watched me watch them. My watching did a thing to her face I could not have anticipated: it loosened something that had been clamped for years. I said very little. For once, this seemed the correct call.

The night of the show the street brought its eyes and its coats. The trumpet player was invited and did not play, which felt like a small miracle we were not worthy of. Priya came, with a green scarf that made even her sarcasm seem benevolent. Dawson came and looked at everything with duty and left with relief. People murmured the way they do when they’re translating their feelings into words they hope will be fashionable later. And Iris stood still and did not defend herself. She did not explain. In that room the law was, for a few hours, a small nice dog asleep on the rug.

After they left we sat on the floor and ate toast and she put her head on my knee very briefly and then immediately apologized for the entire concept of knees. I put my hand very near her hair and then remembered to move my hand and did. She laughed in her throat and did a small shiver.

“If I ever disappear, will you have to come find me?” she asked, watching the last of the guests negotiate themselves out the front door.

“Yes,” I said. “It will be tedious for both of us.”

“I intend to carry a map on my skin,” she said, and then sat up. “I’ve been thinking about doing a bigger one. Not a flower, not something with names. Something that will make me remember a time I need to remember. I don’t know if it’s right. I don’t know if it will scare the people who get scared.”

“Scaring the right people is a hobby you could list on forms,” I said. “As long as you don’t scare yourself.”

“I don’t,” she said, and then made a face, because we had both caught the lie mid-jump. “All right. I do. But I still want it.”

She looked at my face the way the city looks at the cathedral when the trees go shy. “Would you come with me? When I go. Just to walk me there. Just so that when I step out again there is a person who remembers the before.”

I agreed, without understanding that we were going somewhere I would no longer be able to follow. I said yes because my mouth has learned to say yes faster than my nervous system can catch it and negotiate.

You will want, later, to measure the distance between this moment and another, much sharper one, with a ruler. You will want steps to count. But there is a point at which counting is not the equal of knowing. You put your hand on a door. You open it. The room beyond is always larger than the hinges imply. And even here, even right now, when I tell you that I loved a way to exit and a way to return, I know you will look at me and say that love is a name only, a coat you put on because they gave it to you.

I am putting on the coat.

I am walking out of my house into the kind of January light that pretends to be polite. Iris is on her step with her hands in her pockets, making her shoulders small, and she gives me that look I associate with buses that are just about to arrive. We walk down Holywell Hill, past the window where the hare with antlers looks out, past the shop that sells bulbs caged in delicate wire like little moons they might keep, past a woman with a pink hat who says sorry and does not look sorry. The city bends itself around us.

“Are you frightened?” I ask.

“I am hospitable,” she says. “I am making tea for the fear in my chest and asking it to sit properly while we discuss terms.”

Perpetual Ink, terrible name, is painted black in a way that suggests an argument with color. There are prints on the walls, and a man with long fingers and eyes that look two seconds ahead greets us and says Iris like a secret. She hands him a drawing I have only seen as a blur when she slid it into her pocket by my front door. He nods like a person who has agreed in advance to very little and now finds himself agreeing to more. “You sure?” he asks. “Because this is a—”

“I’m sure,” Iris says.

I wait in the outer room among the magazines that all smell like they were left in the same sun. A woman is talking to her friend about how she hopes her mother will understand. A boy with a scar that makes his eyebrow look impatient is pretending not to be frightened. I pick up a magazine about ink like it is a book about travel and I am going to a country I will not be good at. The music is patient and bass-heavy; it sits in the bones more than the air. Iris disappears behind the curtain.

Three minutes later she reappears and makes a face that means I will be sitting there a while. I do. I think about letters. I think about Saint Alban and a hood. I think about the word permanent and want to argue with it. I write down in my notebook the color of the morning. I write down the exact pattern of the tiles under my feet. My mind tries to be a camera. My mind fails.

After, when she comes out, when she is holding her arm like a person holds something they do not yet know how to name, she is not the same, and I do not mean the ink. She is like a room that has had its furniture quietly rearranged so that your path through it is new. She does not look at me at first. She looks at the window where the street is still hard and ordinary, where the buses still insist, where the woman in the pink hat walks past and is still not sorry.

“You okay?” I ask, stupidly, because my mouth asks what is in front of it.

“I made a decision,” she says, and the way she says decision makes me wonder how many other decisions have sat in her chest like small, stubborn animals.

“Can I see?” I ask, and she lets me.

I look. I wish now I had not, which is not to say I blame the looking. Some images go into you clean and set up a room. Others arrive with their own weather. This one wasn’t a flower or a map. It wasn’t a word. It wasn’t a bird taking off or an anchor deciding to give up. It was— I should not try to describe it and I will anyway, because what else is there to do. It was a shape I recognized from nowhere and everywhere, like a sickness a city gets in winter on all its windows. It ran up her forearm like a vine that had learned geometry, and at its center there was a negative space, an absence, that pulled the eye and held it. It was exquisitely done. It was beautiful. It was a mark that said: Now I have joined myself.

I did not say any of that. I said nothing. I sat with my mouth closed while the ink dried and my pulse went into the wrong room. She covered it again, tucked her hand into her pocket, and we walked out together, and the air was the same and not. The sky decided to make weather after all, a little rain that did not ask permission.

On the walk home she told me about the buzzing in her bones and about how the man with the long fingers had said, You’ll need to sit with it, like it was a guest she would have to entertain for a while. I nodded and made small noises of agreement. Inside, something was taking inventory. I cannot tell you why my body voted no on a thing that made her say yes; the reasons we give ourselves later are not the reasons at the time. But my blood had a meeting. My skin tried to move away from itself. I thought absurdly of my neat handwriting in Mrs. Marchant’s class, of how pleased she was, and felt the sharp and ridiculous grief of someone who misses a teacher who taught him to not make a mess.

We reached our doors. She turned to me and showed me the corner of it again as if to say, This is the story, and I must love it now for both of us. I smiled then, because I am an expert at smiling when the room expects it. I said, “It suits you,” which is true and was a kindness and also a sentence that sits next to a different sentence I did not say, which is that it did not suit me at all.

I went into my house and put the kettle on and did not make tea. I sat at the table with the pen she had given me and did not write. There are moments when you are pulled to the edge of your own patience with yourself and you think, either I will be someone else now, or I will have to pretend to be more of myself than is reasonable. It is not noble. It is barely tolerable.

That night I dreamed of a room with no corners and woke knowing exactly how many corners my room has. The fox screamed the way foxes do, which is a horror made animal, and somewhere a glass fell in someone’s kitchen and did not break. I lay there and listened to the world perform its small theater, and thought: she has done a thing that will not be undone.

In the morning, as if to reassure myself, I ironed a shirt with such precision it felt violent. I walked to the office with the exact route I always take, counting steps at the parts where I know the cracks. I sat at my desk and put my pen on the paper and did not use it. Priya looked at me and then looked away tactfully; know this about her, she will always give you the privacy to fail. Dawson entered and asked if anyone had seen the file for Mr. Langley and I said, Absent, like I was taking attendance. Everything was the same and not.

I did not see Iris that day. Or the next. I thought of her as a page turned and me as a reader who is not ready, and then corrected myself, because I am not allowed this dramatics. I walked home the long way once, detouring through the market and then the car park, which is to say I pretended to have a reason to be wholly elsewhere. My chest did an excellent imitation of carrying something heavy.

When I saw her again, three days later, she was talking with Mrs. Pell on the pavement about a plant that had decided to die and I had the urge to ask the plant for help. I am a rational person. You would not know it now. She saw me, and waved, and that wave did a very specific thing to the inside of my mouth that made me feel I had been caught; she came nearer.

“You look like someone,” she said, “who has been in a room with a very smart child and a very broken kettle.”

“The kettle is obviously an allegory,” I said, “and the child is time.”

She smiled and touched my sleeve with one finger, very gently, as if testing whether the cloth had made up its mind. “Come over?” she asked. “I want to show you something, and I promise it isn’t my arm again.”

I went. Of course I went. We are all, in the end, complicit in ourselves. The room was arranged differently, the paintings shifted to make room for a thing that wasn’t there. On the couch was a stack of letters tied with string like something people do in films. She untied them and let them spill and one fell to the ground and I saw my name. Not my name. The name Bret in someone else’s hand, written years ago, a pen pressing down too hard, the way we write when we are nervous or sixteen. She picked it up and pressed it into my hand.

“What’s this?” I asked, and she put her hair behind her ear in the way I have told you before and I will tell you again and again because you must understand this in order to forgive me.

“A letter I wrote when I was a person who put all the words in the world in bad places,” she said. “You don’t have to read it. I am not one of those people who makes other people read old maps. I only want you to know there was a map.”

I held the paper as if it would bite. I did not read it. I did not ask her to explain. I was gentle and normal and precise. We had tea and did not make the tea perform. We left the letters like a mess on the couch because sometimes you have to leave a mess to convince yourself you can be a person who owns things.

Later that evening, the trumpet played and we could hear it through our walls at the exact same angle. Iris laughed and leaned her head back and when she did, the collar of her shirt slipped and I saw again the edge of the thing on her skin, and I felt a movement in me that you would be right to call fear, though at the time I dressed it more politely. It sat with me at my table later as if it had been invited. It went to bed and got into my side and waited. It is still here, sometimes, when the bells roll down the hill and the city tells itself a story about a man who put on someone else’s hood and decided that meant something. I want it to mean something. I want everything to mean something. I want that to be allowed.

That night I took the three candles out of their paper and set them on my mantel. I lit one. It burned like it had been practicing. I sat in the chair that has a hollow where I always sit, and I watched the light do its slow work, and I put my hand out into it and then took it back. Outside, the fox made a sound like a hinge. The trumpet paused as if it had been told a secret. The candle burned down to the point where you could blow it out and leave the night to finish the sentence. I did not blow it out. I let it decide. I thought, not for the first time, that a person’s life is a story they tell to the person they hope to be, and that the person who listens is always a liar. I thought, in the quiet, that I had been given an invitation. I thought, in the quiet that is never quiet enough, that I was not ready. I thought, and I thought, and the candle, polite and determined, did what it had always been made to do.The next morning the city put on a coat of frost that made the pavements a little theatrical. Breath hung in front of faces like trial balloons, and the light decided to behave the way light behaves when it has been given rules and is trying not to touch anything it shouldn’t. I left my house early because sleep had been polite and brief; it had set me at the edge of the bed at five and said, Good luck with your day, and I had shook its hand and gone downstairs out of habit. The fox had not yet finished his rounds and looked at me as if to say we were both too eager. The candle I had allowed to complete itself had left a small crater of wax like the map of a country that used to exist. I tidied around it with a care that would have embarrassed me if anyone had been present, because it felt like tidying around a decision.

At the cathedral a man with a broom swept stone in wide arcs that made a sound like the beginning of rain. The nave was empty the way a room is empty when it is waiting to be good, which is different than the way it is empty after everyone has gone home. A notice near the door said Candlemas in a script that tried to be plain and almost was. I stood in the cool and said my secular prayers, which are mostly just names of people I hope continue to exist. In a side chapel a woman with a coat sensible enough to survive any age lit a thin candle and the flame made a small, competent vow. I did not light one. I did not feel worthy of adding to the arithmetic when I had candles at home that asked their own questions.

On my way back, Iris was standing in the small bay window like someone who had been arranged there by a considerate director. The aftermath of ink had made a slight discipline of the way she held her arm, a choreography that asked for space between fabric and skin. She saw me and waved with the other hand, and I did a complicated gesture with my scarf as if my scarf were a person with feelings. She opened her door before I was quite at mine, and the air between the two houses did a little contraction that my body noticed before my head did.

“How is your guest?” I asked, because that seemed safer than asking how she was, which is sometimes an ambush disguised as care.

“He is quiet and imperious and would like to be introduced to everyone as soon as possible so he can make decisions,” she said, smiling with only the middle of her mouth, and I saw the shine of the dressing under her sleeve and tried not to fall in love with the fact of care. “It’s fine. It’s not fine. It’s like the weather having an opinion about my arm.”

“Good,” I said, and then immediately corrected, because this is my specialty, repairing sentences as they leave my mouth. “Not good, but… you.”

“I am,” she said, and for a brief moment the most ordinary word we own sounded like a clean instrument.

At work, Priya looked at my face in the way a doctor looks at the color of a person’s nails, and I made a noise that pretended to be the sound competent men make when they are asked to lift piano lids. She handed me coffee and a stack of files and said, “You’re early, which means the world is either ending or beginning. We have Langley at eleven, and the girl’s review has been moved to this afternoon if the magistrate’s stomach can bear it.”

“The magistrate’s stomach,” I said, trying on a grin like a tie, “has survived lunches that would have felled a younger man.”

She tilted her head and did not pursue the joke, and I appreciated her silence the way you appreciate a well-timed hand on your shoulder that does not linger. The case files lay there in their elastic bands like sandwiches wrapped too tightly, and I imagined unwrapping them and finding different fillings than the ones the law allows. Mr. Langley’s documents had that very specific smell of paper that has decided to be important and is only half right about it. The money that takes a walk on a hot day had not yet decided to come home, and Dawson had written in his neat slanted script the kind of sentence that suggests more is known than can be said aloud. It looked like the beginning of a short, unsatisfactory poem.

At eleven, Dawson went first because that is what he does, and the room rearranged itself around his voice as if it had practice. We discussed the numbers in ways numbers deserve to be discussed, which is to say clearly and with the possibility of being wrong. Dawson suggested phrasing in the letter to Mr. Langley that would make a person feel seen and misdirected at the same time, which is a talent I do not enjoy in other people but admire when the stakes are large. I kept looking at the corner of my own notepaper where I had written Iris’s name in the pen she had given me and had almost written it too large. I pressed the edge of the nib into the paper until the impression showed on the desk through the sheet and then felt a ridiculous flare of shame, as if I had broken something that mattered to someone else. Dawson was describing an escrow that had changed shape when I thought, abruptly, that I did not know what shape I was, and then I remembered I had eaten half a banana in the kitchen and had not finished it, which is the kind of chaos my mind prefers when real chaos is present.

After lunch, the girl sat on the bench with her hands clasped in that performance of innocence that teenagers do when innocence is a negotiation with theatre. She was smaller than the file implied. Her mother sat behind her with her mouth pursed into an emblem, and a man whose job it is to make options narrower than they start out being shifted papers as if he were preparing to perform surgery on a very stubborn organ. I spoke calmly because if you do not give people calm at these moments you give them nothing.

“She went,” I said to the room softly, “to the edge of a place and measured herself against it. She was wrong to take property, but she was not wrong to take herself to a shoreline and see what the air does there. We make the mistake, often, of treating teenage navigation as crime when it is just navigation with poor signage.”

The magistrate looked at me from behind a pair of glasses that have seen many navigations, and his mouth did a small thing, and I knew I had the room for a minute. The girl did not look at me, because to look at me would have been to accept an adult handand she was not ready to be seen by anyone who did not know her washing powder. I saw the mother’s chin tremble and then stop, like a small animal that has decided against bolting. We got what we needed, which is to say a little more time and a little less punishment, and I carried that win like a pebble I placed carefully on a shelf.

On my way back to Clarence Road the air had decided to be kind about the cold. The woman with the pink hat was arguing with a man about whether the milk was off, and the argument had in it the entire skeleton of a marriage I did not want to think about. Outside the greengrocer, the older woman with the herbs stood with a bag of parsley that had not been given the choice but to be beautiful. She saw me and did that particular British thing where you do not greet someone until they are exactly within greeting distance, and then greet them as if greeting had been inevitable all along.

“You’re Bret,” she said, making my name sound like something she would keep safe in a drawer because she had always collected useful things. “I’ve seen you weighing oranges like you’re measuring truth. I’m Mina. Sometimes I make Iris eat soup. It is work, but I am committed to my craft.”

“I’m grateful to anyone who can persuade someone to eat soup,” I said. “It is the only honest food.”

She smiled and handed me the parsley as if I had earned it. “You are a talker,” she said. “But you have the look of someone practicing not talking. You know of her letters?”

“I saw them,” I said, and then stopped because it sounded like a confession and she did not need my confessions unless she asked for them. “She showed me a stack. She said I did not have to read them.”

“She kept them,” Mina said, looking not at me but at a point just past my shoulder like she was watching a future queue for bread. “Sometimes she writes ahead, and when she gets to the place she wrote about, she puts the letters down on the table and sees if the room is true to the map. She wrote to a man named Bret years ago. She liked the mouth shape of it. She’s superstitious like that, but not the small superstitions that make you stupid. The useful ones. She writes to doors and knocks afterwards. It’s a kind of magic that won’t owe anyone interest.”

“Did she post them?” I asked, picturing envelopes like birds with nowhere to land.

“No,” Mina said, in the tone people use when someone has asked whether a person went swimming in a river in winter. “That would be a curse, and she doesn’t do curses. She writes and ties and keeps and then unties and lets the past air out and then ties again. It’s how some of us don’t drown. Don’t make a face at me as if I have said the wrong thing, it isn’t a tragedy unless you point at it until it performs.”

I did not know I had made a face. I thanked her for the parsley because manners are the last fence left to us in an untidy world. She touched my arm briefly, the way people do when they want to know if you are a temperature they understand, and then she was gone. I watched her go with the astonished affection I keep discovering I have for strangers who know more about me than I do.

That evening Iris knocked with a small jar in her hand and an expression that suggested the jar had been born difficult and she was being patient with it. “Ointment,” she said. “Do not be alarmed by how it smells like a decision made by a forest.”

“I am familiar with forests that make decisions,” I said, stepping aside, and she wandered to my kitchen as if she had signed an agreement with my countertops and could therefore lean on them without guilt. “Mina gave me parsley. She said soup.”

“She believes soup can fix a country,” Iris said. “She isn’t wrong. She once improved a very bad marriage with carrots and patience. The marriage undid itself a year later, but everyone ate well.”

“Do you want to sit?” I asked, because standing was a choreography we were both tiring of. “Do you want tea?”

“I want,” she said, and then paused like a person locating a word they had left in another room. “I want to ask you if you are angry at me for being a person.”

I wish I could tell you I said the correct thing immediately. There is a version of me who is very good at being good. He makes cameos and is then unavailable for long stretches. I put the kettle on and it made the complaint it makes when it has been asked to work before it is emotionally ready.

“I’m not angry,” I said, which was true and cheap. “I am… finding out that the parts of me that like to put things on shelves are not always friendly to the part of me that wants to live entirely in the middle of a room.”

“I made my skin an argument,” she said, sitting at the table and touching the jar to the wood like a respectful knock. “I did it because I was tired of not arguing. I can see that when I lift my sleeve now, I am making you look at a thing you did not subscribe to. I don’t want you to look if looking hurts you, but I also cannot carry myself like a smuggled package. These two truths do not kiss easily.”

“I like your sleeve,” I said, and we both laughed at the idiocy of that sentence, and somehow the laugh did more good than anything else we might have tried. I made tea. I made it with my whole back, which is how I make tea when I want to appear like a domestic person the world can rely on. Iris watched me and her face softened the way faces do when they decide to forgive at least one thing in the room.

“Do you want to see something that is not my skin?” she asked when we had both distracted ourselves with sips. “I don’t mean art, exactly, but it is a cousin.”

She went back next door and said, “Two minutes,” and then came back with a small square wooden box. It was the kind of box that belonged to people in nineteenth-century novels who keep hair and decisions in cedar. She set it on the table and opened it, and inside were small squares of color on paper, like paint had decided to complete itself into a deck. She laid them out, patient, each with a pencil line of date. The shades moved from honest greens to dishonest blues to reds that almost dared you to say the word red out loud. I put my hand near them, not on them, because sometimes touching is a violation even at the level of ink.

“What are they?” I asked, although the answer was also there, obvious, like a friend you have not met yet but have seen in a photograph.

“A day,” she said. “I’ve painted every day for a year. Not pictures. Not subjects. Just the weather of it. I try to make a color that is the closest I can get to what the day was asking, and then I write down the date and the time I knew and I put it in the box. Sometimes I get the color wrong and it haunts me for a week. Sometimes I get it and the rightness makes me too proud and then I leave the lid off to teach myself humility. This one—” She tapped a pale, cold blue with a small coil of gray crouched inside. “This one is the day my sister called me after a long silence and told me about the house with no corners. I didn’t know how to make that color, so I made the color of not knowing. This one—” She touched a warm, indecent gold. “This is the first time I sold something that did not feel like treachery. This one is the morning you told me about a hedge that wanted to be a country.”

“Do I get a color?” I asked, lightly, and then closed my mouth because sometimes you ask for a thing and then you remember you don’t know what it will mean to have it.

“You do,” she said, and she did not reach for a new square. She lifted the lid of the box and there, on the inside of it where the wood had darkened in the shape of keeping, she had painted a small, disciplined line of ink that was neither blue nor black but the exact color of the corner of my suit where the fabric catches morning. “I gave it to the box,” she said. “Because not everything wants to be on paper.”

“I want to kiss you,” I said, and it was the first time I had let a sentence leave my mouth without a permit, and it crossed the air between us without looking for crossings.

She set the paint square down slowly and looked at me with every part of her face, which is a kindness people do not extend nearly enough. “You may,” she said, and then, a heartbeat later, “You don’t have to.”

We stepped toward each other like people who had been warned about a floor but had decided to trust their feet anyway. Her hand moved to my arm, below the place where her own skin was tender, and she said, quietly, “I will not show you what I am not ready to show you, and you will not look for what I do not offer, and we will be two people in a room with a good map.” Then she kissed me, and the room reorganized itself around the new geography, and nothing important was broken. My body did a very small flinch when her sleeve grazed my wrist near the place I know us both to be shy. She felt it and paused and rested her forehead against mine like a person leaning on a doorframe in a strange house, and then I made the deliberate choice to put my hands around the back of her neck where skin is less about decision and more about kindness, and I kissed her again and did not even notice what the trumpet was doing somewhere out there in the ongoing Thursday of the world.

After, we sat with the box open between us and the tea cold because tea does not like to be ignored. Iris put the lid on, reverent, and did the jar ritual with her arm while we talked in the way you talk when you have just returned from somewhere you could not take pictures. She told me about the sound design job where she made a room in London feel like the bottom of a swimming pool and the CEO of a company cried because his mother had taught him to swim in water that smelled like pennies. I told her about Mr. Langley and the language people use when they cannot say stealing but cannot bear to say mistake. The evening slid into us without having to knock. When she left, she put her hand on the doorframe and said, “Tomorrow, come to the cathedral with me if you can. They will do a thing with candles and very old music and I would like to pretend with you that we are always this old and very young.”

In the cathedral at Candlemas, the world was persuaded into being a different shape for an hour. The nave was dark in a way only old rooms are allowed to be dark; there is a contract somewhere that specifies this. People held small flames like birds learning to trust the hand. The choir did not try to be surprising, and their refusal was a kind of relief. We stood near a pillar carved by a person whose hands must have ached for days and watched light move across faces as if it were considering who to forgive. Iris’s fingers were cool and dry, and when she took my hand later in the hymn that everyone pretended to know, I felt a precise gratitude that I have rarely felt without wanting to bargain for more. A child a few rows ahead tried to blow his candle out and his mother put her hand gently over his and said, Not yet, and the not yet landed on my tongue like a small medicine.

In the soft noise of coats and whispers afterwards, Iris tipped her head toward the Lady Chapel like someone indicating a café. We moved that way and she stopped just inside the threshold, a place where people leave flowers for their dead and prayers that do not have addresses. She looked at the altar and then at me.

“My father hated these rooms,” she said, not asking me to approve of him. “He said they made people sentimental and useless, and he said that like it was both one thing and two. He liked to fix engines the way some people like to fix sentences. He took me once to a service like this and stood the whole time like a person being inspected, and afterwards he said something that sounded like contempt but was really fear. He is frightened of things that ask him to put down his tools. He does not know what his hands are for when they are not full.”

“My father loved a tap,” I said, because sometimes you owe the room an offering, even if it is only a domestic one. “We would go to houses and he would show me that if you listen long enough you can hear where water is hiding. He would be very suspicious of your box of colors.”

“He would be right to be,” she said, and we smiled at two men who will never meet, and perhaps that is for the best. We walked out into the nearly-night and the bell did a quiet inside-my-throat sound, and at that exact moment a boy with a trumpet walked past us, a case under his arm, and we looked at each other like children who have just seen a mythical animal decide to be ordinary.

We followed him because our honesty is selective. He turned down a street I know like the seams of an old jacket and went into the square where people who do not wish to be found practice not being found. He took his trumpet out and did not do anything foolish like looking around to make sure he had an audience, and he began to play an unambitious scale that still found a way to argue with the air. We stood at the edge of a bench and did not sit and did not apologize for standing. After a while, he noticed us and lifted his chin in the international sign for Are you going to make this into a problem.

“You’re good on Thursdays,” Iris said, the way you would address someone whose dog you have been admiring.

He shrugged and did the trumpet equivalent of a smile. “I like the echo.”

“Do you like making your neighbors hate you on purpose?” I asked, because I am still, despite my efforts, a petty man sometimes.

“They can come find me,” he said. “It gives people something to do. It is better than them going home and committing small crimes with their phones. Anyway, I’m not always playing. Only on the days that have edges.”

“Today has edges,” Iris said, and the boy nodded like a person who has decided she is not a threat and perhaps an ally. He put the trumpet down. “Do you play for someone?” she asked, and he looked at her in a quick, assessing way, and then his whole face changed like a room that has decided to open its curtains.

“My sister,” he said, eyes on the protective felt of his case. “She’s in the hospital until she decides to stop pretending. She pretends she’s fine and then her body argues with her. I go there and play on Thursdays because the nurse I like works then and lets me stand under the window in the stupid courtyard with the stupid bins. They won’t let me closer because I am contagious because I am a person. I come here first, to warm up. The buildings here listen better than the hospital does.”

“We hear you sometimes,” I said, which felt like a confession and a compliment. “I was going to submit a petition to the council.”

“Do,” he said, grinning with relief I did not know I was capable of causing. “Pretend I am a menace. It makes me feel like I’m not being ignored.”

“Good,” Iris said softly, and there was a shape of pride in her voice that had nothing to do with him and everything to do with a person deciding not to flinch. We left him to his scales and walked back on streets that had changed their names without telling anyone.

In the days after, my house learned a new rhythm that included the sound of Iris’s knuckles against my door and my own reluctant bag of oranges telling me I was allowed to be clumsy sometimes. I went to Perpetual Ink alone once, because sometimes a person will go to the edge of a picture to see if the paint will chip. The man with the long fingers looked up, and his face did not move much, and he said, “You’re fine,” as if I had asked him to read my fortune. I looked at the prints on the wall and understood none of them and half all of them. There was a sketch pinned near the counter, of a shape like the one I had seen on Iris’s arm, except it was not finished, and in the margin in a hand not quite disciplined enough for the job someone had written absence in a very particular shade of pencil. I did not ask, and he did not tell, and we had a perfect conversation.

Back at the office, the Langley situation grew legs. Money has a habit of taking not only walks but also holidays, and we were now required to draft a letter that would be sent to a man who wore shirts that have their own budget, gently suggesting that the firm where he has always kept whatever he could not be bothered keeping track of had, for reasons temporary and technical, mislaid a sum that could be described as uncomfortable. Dawson asked me to write a sentence that would make guilt sound like weather. I wrote: “In the course of reconciling accounts that, due to the unprecedented circumstances of the last quarter, have not been as current as we would ordinarily maintain, certain transfers have proven difficult to substantiate, though we anticipate swift clarity.” I hated me and my education a little, and then I did what you do and printed it and put it on a desk and watched as someone else signed their name to it. Priya caught my eye and did not offer solace, because we had used an entire week’s supply of it on the girl at the shoreline.

That evening, in a small act of penance I may have imagined, I went to Mrs. Pell to buy bread and eggs and she told me a story about the time her husband put too many bulbs in a patch of dirt and the spring had a tantrum. Iris came in halfway through and bought lemons and honey and a newspaper she would not read, and we walked out together and she said, “Would you like to see the painting I turned to face the wall again because it refused to be moral?”

It was not so much a painting of a body as it was the idea of bone in light. The collarbone that had made me want to confess was there, but not as a seduction; it was there as a hinge. Another line curved with the modesty of someone who had decided to be naked without inviting anyone to comment on it. The colors were not colors you would use if you were trying to sell anything. They were the colors left at the bottom of a palette after a day, the ones you get when you mix decisions. It was beautiful and disturbing and I loved it in the way you love something that has already made up its mind.

“You see why I turned it,” she said, and I said yes although I did not, entirely, and it is possible she knew that about me. “Some things need a wall to think. Some things need looking. I wish sometimes that I could be more decisive about which are which.”

“You could do what Dawson does,” I said, because I am rude when I am tender sometimes. “You could sign a letter that says both and neither.”

“Ah yes,” she said. “And then make soup.”

We ate in my kitchen because kitchens like to tell you their own stories and are less earnest about it than dining rooms. The soup was Mina’s and tasted like someone had paid attention to carrots. We ate on stools, because chairs felt too formal for broth. Iris kept her sleeve rolled more to her elbow that night, and I looked and did not look, and she saw me doing both, and neither of us apologized. After we had done the dishes, which we did with an argument about which sponge is best for pans, which we enjoyed more than we should have, we stood very close because the kitchen is a small legal jurisdiction and we had both violated several ordinances already. She put her hand on the back of my head and I put my hand at her waist and we kissed like we were saying thank you to the same invisible benefactor.

There were still moments when my body did its small animal thing and shifted away from the line of ink like it had been taught by an unwise ancestor to avoid certain plants. I told it, gently, to be quiet, and it obeyed as well as bodies ever obey their owners. Iris noticed when I was brave and when I wasn’t, and neither of those seem to be the parts of me she was tabulating for a verdict.

One late afternoon, when the light pretended to return at four and then withdrew the promise like a politician, Mina came by with a Tupperware and a look. She did not knock in the way most people knock; she announced herself with the scraping of her shoe on the mat like a cricket. Iris let her in and they stood in the hall and did small dances with their hands. I stayed on the couch, eyes on a book I was only pretending to be reading.

“You told him about the letters,” Mina said, voice low but not secret. “Good.”

“I showed him,” Iris said. “I didn’t tell him the parts that belong to me.”

“Tell him the parts that he thinks belong to him,” Mina said. “It will save you both time later.”

“I am telling you both now,” Iris said, raising her voice just enough to let me in on the fact that I had been let in deliberately, “that I wrote a letter once to someone I had not met and it said his name and it was the wrong person and I sent it anyway and it was a mess and then I learned not to do that. I keep them now because keeping is a kindness. This is not a coded thing meant to make you perform, Bret, it is a confession of an old method. I do not want you to be jealous of a girl who loved a person she had invented. There are real people to be jealous of, and we can timetable them.”

We all laughed then, the kind of laugh that says yes to the right joke and no to the wrong ones. I put the book down without pretending further and went to the hall and took the Tupperware from Mina like a notary. “You will be all right,” she said to me, and I would have liked to know whether she meant tonight, or this month, or the year, or the great abstract elevator that will one day take us all down to the ground floor, but I did not ask her to be precise.

When she had gone, Iris turned to me and looked like the sort of person who can taste iron in water. “I do not want to mislead you,” she said. “The mark on my arm is not about you, and it is not not about you. It is about the part of me that promised, long ago, not to let a certain thing happen to me again. No one broke me. I am not doing this to rebuke anyone. I am putting a rope around the pit in the ground and writing the word pit around it in very large letters so that when I walk I can see where I must not step. That is the absence. I do not know if you are the kind of person who will pretend you do not see a rope when someone has put one there. I hope you are not. Sometimes men are terrible at ropes.”

“I am excellent at ropes in theory,” I said, with a seriousness that surprised me. “In practice I will need to be told I am at the edge because my eyes are not clever and I have been taught to look at the sky to see if the weather is coming.”

She put her hand over my mouth the way you do not put your hand over someone’s mouth in public, and I kissed her palm in a way that made her criticize me later for being glib and then agree to it again six minutes after that. We were ridiculous and correct.

It is necessary, too, to say that in that same week my neat life put its elbow on the wrong lever. Dawson called me into his office at the end of a day that had already given me seven reasons to pretend to faint, and he said, with the weariness that makes men perform their dignity too loudly, that Langley had found the sums himself, mis-shelved in a spreadsheet like a book put away under the wrong initial. We would be able to say that our letter had produced clarity. He was pleased with himself in a way that made me want to dress him in humility. Priya rolled her chair to my doorway after and said, “I suppose we have not been invited to drown ourselves in the Ver in penance,” and I said, “No,” and then, because the room needed it, “But we could go to the park and listen to the geese swear.”

We did. We sat on the damp bench and watched the river lecture itself into curves, and the crows patrolled like moralists who had forgotten their first point, and the ducks had arguments with themselves and won and lost them in the same gulp. Priya took a small metal flask from her coat with deliberate theatre and produced a drink that had the decency to be harsh. She offered and I accepted and the heat it made in my throat felt like a hand on my sternum telling me to sit still.

“You look like someone who is learning a new language,” she said after a while. “The kind they don’t teach at school, because school panics at nuance. You are excellent with nuance at work. It appears you are less excellent at it when your shirt is off.”

“I don’t like to be inelegant in front of people,” I said, and she snorted and looked away at the exact right angle to make the snort love instead of cruelty.

“You should try it,” she said. “You may find the person you are really very competent at falling on his face. Some of us measure our competence in wrong units. Do you want to tell me the honoring version of what is happening, or do you want to tell me the version where you come off better. I am available for both.”

“She put a thing on her arm,” I said, because I had to name it somewhere. “And my body decided to be cowardly, and then my brain tried to pretend my body had made a typo. I am working on my body’s literacy. Also there are letters. And a boy with a trumpet who is preventing the apocalypse.”

“Good,” she said after a long pause, during which a goose made a noise like a derogatory memoir. “I approve of almost everything you just said. It is appalling that you had to get a girlfriend before realizing that bodies are part of the bargain and not just devices for transporting heads and briefcases.”

“She is not— we have not—” I said, and then gave up the ditch because it was not worth defending. “She told me about a rope around a pit. I think there is a rope around a pit. I am not good at identifying pits.”

“You are excellent at documentation,” she said. “Draw a map. Put a rope on it. Write pit where necessary. And then for once in your life do not argue with a woman who knows what she is talking about when she says, Here, the ground gives way. Also, do not be jealous of old letters. Jealousy of paper is the most humiliating of male sports.”

“I will put away my green ribbon,” I said. “I will write in my little book, Pit here, and try to remember not to picnic on its edge.”

“Good boy,” she said, which I should have hated and did not. We watched the river keep being water and not morals. The cathedral peeped over the trees like an ancient friend who does not want to intrude. We went home and the city did not mind.

The next morning there was a note on my step with a fish that had corrected its own smile. It said, Back Thursday, Arundel. It turned out she had taken a train to a town she liked because the lines on the map there were satisfying, and she sent me a photograph of a castle and a river that had decided to be decorative. I read the note and read an entire library of other things into it because I am my own enemy sometimes. I wanted, absurdly, to ask her to take me with her into places where my neatness would be useless and my usefulness would be tested. I wanted to do my work and to sit and not be good. I am no longer certain I will get to have both. I put the note on my mantel with the candle crater and the pen, and I left it there like a person who knows he is building a mantel the way other people build altars and is too prudent to call it that out loud.

She returned on Thursday smelling like rain that had learned manners in a different town. We met on the path without needing to pretend we were surprised, and she told me about a woman selling sandwiches who said Arundel like it was a verb, and how she watched a child say no to a dog very politely and how the dog obeyed because politeness is a language dogs like to practice. She had bought me a postcard of a medieval figure with a sword who looked like a person in a good suit and a bad mood, and she had written on the back, For the days when the law sharpens itself on you, and I put it on the fridge with a magnet shaped like a lemon because that is where it looked pleased.

That night, the trumpet did not play. The fox did not scream. The street made a pause, and the pause held. Iris sat on my floor because chairs are less honest than floors, her sleeve rolled, her arm a new map I was learning to read with the right kind of caution, and we spoke like people who had decided to be both old and very young in the same hour. When I went to bed, I did not do the inventory of corners. I lay on my back and let the dark take attendance, and for once I did not worry that it would mark me absent. Somewhere, in a drawer, a letter with my name in someone else’s hand waited, and I did not open it. I looked at the ceiling until it blurred into a color I could not name, and I thought, I could get good at this, and a part of me that has never trusted anything agreed out loud.The week decided to open with an envelope that had the humor to pretend it was just paper. It waited on Iris’s step with its serious blue lettering like something you ought to put down before you realized that you were holding it at all.
