The corner of the paper had gone soft from being carried around the living room while she decided where to sit with it. She held it up like a specimen she hoped I would identify kindly and said, “It says Notice,” and then added, as if quoting a particularly ungenerous friend, “Section Twenty-One.” She said the number with an accuracy that made the air around it respectful.

My body did its professional rearrangement. Even in a doorway with oranges plotting their mutiny in a bag at my feet, you can feel your organs pick up clipboards and take attendance. I took it, and I did the quick read you do when the blood is busy and you have to look like you can persuade it to stand still. It was what it was: time dressed in legal language. Sixty days offered like a joke without a punchline. The name of a letting agent with a logo that tried for inheritance and landed on dentistry. A signature that had practiced being important.

“Did he speak to you?” I asked, keeping my voice in the register you use when children have just woken up from a troubling dream and you have agreed to pretend there are no monsters in the wardrobe while the monsters themselves write a polite letter.

“Only by van,” she said, smiling without moving her mouth. “He was outside yesterday with a ladder doing something aristocratic to a gutter, and when I waved the wave you wave at ladders he executed a very precise look in the opposite direction. This arrived after lunch. Mina told me to sit down with it on a hard chair, the way you sit with guests you are not inclined to coddle.”

“It is not a surprise,” I said to the part of her that did not want the words and to the part that expected them anyway. “It is, however, not the end. There are rules about deposits and clocks and how you say a thing before you get to do it. We can make the clock behave for you for now.”

“Make the clock behave,” she said, tasting the words as if they were soup and needed salt. “I thought that is what the candles were for.”

“The candles are for the soul,” I said, not entirely in jest. “The letters are for the clock.”

She stood aside and I followed her into the house that had just been told by an envelope that it might have to stop being itself. The room felt like a person who has put their hands in their pockets to be polite. On the mantel the jar for her arm sat like an appointment, and on the windowsill the plant did its best impression of optimism. She put the letter on the table as if it might leap off and confess its motives if it thought no one was looking.

“I don’t want to go yet,” she said, almost diffident with the confession. “I have just told the walls that they have work to do and they have not yet finished being what I asked them to be. I know houses are not dogs. I know they do not come when you call. I just—”

“You are allowed to want,” I said, which is an absurdity that occasionally still needs saying out loud. “We will make the timetable tell the truth about itself. Let me see your tenancy, and the deposit, and any versions of conversations you have had with him, and what the world thinks your notice period is. Sometimes there are small errors. Sometimes those errors are enough to make the universe revise its plans.”

She put a hand over the paper in a way that would have been an oath if there had been a book under it. “You will not wear your tie at me,” she said. “I mean— you will not become a man made entirely of velcro and Latin at me. I would like you to be Bret in a jumper.”

“I will be Bret in a jumper,” I said, which was true in both the literal and the complicated sense. “My Latin is in a drawer. I will only take it out if the letter is rude in a language I can’t persuade with English.”

We did the work, which is to say we put the kettle on as the universe requires before we do anything that intends to change another thing. She had the papers in a folder more dignified than our purpose deserved; the deposit had been put somewhere correct but late; the gas certificate had missed a year the way years sometimes fall through the cracks of people who have decided to be careless as a hobby. I took notes in my small book with the pen she had found in a video in Japan, and it felt like using a scalpel to slice bread. When I used words like compliance they landed in the room and did not ruin it, which is a skill I wish I always had.

“We can write,” I said, and she nodded like writing was a verb she could endorse. “We can ask for clarification with the sort of politeness that makes men behave. We can ask for the mistakes to make themselves useful. We can make the clock say a different hour.”

“You say we very beautifully,” she said, racking two mugs on top of one another as if building a little shelter. “You say it like a verb instead of like a pronoun.”

“It is always better when we can be a verb,” I said. “Pronouns are fine for introductions. Verbs repair gutters.”

Afterwards, when we had put the paper back into its temporary coffin and the letter into a sleeve as if it were contagious, we sat, and the room returned to being a room where two people had lived for an hour instead of a courtroom in a cardigan. She rested her forearm on the table, and the dressing shone, a neat admission that bodies insist on time when time misbehaves.

“It is a cruelty,” she said, looking at the window without seeing it, “how rooms have to unlearn you. All your shapes go out of them like the tide, and they sit there as if no one had ever put down a cup and left a small witness ring. I am not noble. I have not earned the right to be moved.”

“No one asks nobility from the moved,” I said, and the part of me that knows what words do felt the small heat that comes when one lands near the right place. “The only noble thing here is the kettle.”

She laughed then, sudden and grateful and more for herself than for me. “Good,” she said. “Good kettle. Brave kettle. We will write to the man in the van and tell him that he must also become a kettle.”

We did. Priya, later, took my draft and softened three things and sharpened two and removed one sentence that had been included for the pleasure of seeing if I could write it, which is a bad habit I pretend is not a habit. She read the notice with her eyebrows making their very specific shapes and said, “Deposits are always the weak link because men like to keep small suns in drawers,” and I loved her for the way she can be both tender and clinical without contaminating either. Dawson peered at the letter and said something florid about the rights of tenants that I will not repeat because it will ruin your supper, and then looked at me with a paternal benevolence that sat on him like a hat that had been left too near a radiator.

Before the letter could make its journey with stamps attached like confident birds, Thursday came and with it the boy and his precise noise. The square behind the hospital had bins that had once been yellow and now were the color of tobacco. The courtyard has an acoustics that was clearly designed by a committee of very clean people. The nurse with the braid and the authority of a person who knows where syringes live stood in a doorway and pretended not to watch. Iris, alert to languages I barely hear, had asked if she could come and listen and say nothing, and the boy had made the shrug that is a yes when you are sixteen and practicing how to carry permission without letting it leak.

He played scales like fences and then like rivers. At one point he did something no trumpet owes anyone, a soft unambitious melody that turned the air into a small apology. I stood with my coat unbuttoned because I wanted to be honest to the cold. Iris put her hand in mine half-way through a note that made a particular window on the third floor decide to tremble, and I had the brief and pure sensation of being included. A shadow moved in that window, and then a wrist and then a palm and then the absence of gesture that is sometimes more eloquent than any wave. I did not know if the sister saw us; I suspected that even if she had, the seeing would have been for herself.

A security guard with shoes softened by long corridors approached and did the thing that makes me respect men in uniforms: he looked like he was rehearsing the kind of authority that could hold the room and then chose not to perform it in public. He nodded to the boy and said, “Three more minutes,” and the boy made a sound with his lips that meant, to my amazement, gratitude. Iris did something subtle with her body, an angle of her shoulders and the tilt of her head, and the sound changed in a way that made the space around us feel like it had been re-tuned. Afterwards, when the nurse with the braid spoke to us, she said, “Thank you for being small,” and I wrote that down, because it is not a sentence I had expected and I want to be asked, again, to make myself less of a problem.

On the way back we walked through streets that have decided to be deeply themselves in February. The shop that sells bulbs in cages had replaced moons with stars in smaller cages. The charity shop had admitted a piano that took up important breathing room and was called SPLENDID on a paper sign by someone who had not played it. The boy had told us the sister’s name. It lives in my mouth now like a fragile instrument and I will not put it here because not everything is ours.

“My mother used to call Thursday small Friday,” Iris said, stepping over a puddle that had pretensions to be a lake. “She was always trying to get the week to move faster, as if she had somewhere to be that did not involve us. When I was little I would hide her keys, which is a terrible thing I am not proud of, but I would do it and then cry when she left anyway because you cannot ever hide what a person has decided to be. I think I am sometimes hiding keys still, and I would like to apologize to anyone who has been late because of me.”

“I was late the day I saw you,” I said, which is partly true and mostly myth, and the truth is something like a rope around a pit anyway.

“Then you have forgiven me in advance,” she said, and the look she gave me did useful things to the architecture of my throat.

That night I spoke to my mother with the ease of a person placing something on a shelf and the difficulty of someone trying to find a shelf that will not immediately come down on his head. She asked me if I was eating, which I answered with a piece of chicken on a plate as evidence, and then she asked me if I was sleeping, which I answered by moving my eyes very slightly away from the camera. She uses the names of days as if they were types of weather. When I told her about Iris, not everything, because I am not good at enough and she is better at it than I am, she said, “An artist, is she,” in the tone that puts an extra comma in the sentence, and I did my best only child thing and said that I had been to services where a thousand candles made strangers into a temporary nation and that I had held a hand in a square behind a building that smelled like disinfectant and promises, and that nothing had burned down, and that sometimes when you do something in a room, the room agrees. She looked at me as if I had managed to use a screwdriver without supervision and told me a story about a neighbour who kept peacocks and never swept their complaints off the path, and I realized that she was telling me she had decided not to be afraid of my news.

It was a small reprieve to go to work and let numbers bite at ankles instead of letters. There was a morning where I lost an hour finding a comma I should not have lost, which is a separate species of shame, and then there was a call from Mr. Langley’s assistant who has a voice like someone who used to teach piano to surgeons, and she told me that Mr. Langley would send a bottle and a note and that he did not like to think of things as mis-shelved, only temporarily disguised as other things, and would I be so good as to assent to his version of the world in writing. I wrote a note that said nothing in the precise way you are taught when you are first given a suit, and I put it in an envelope that did not deserve my name on it. When the bottle arrived, Dawson opened it with the relish of a man playing at ships, and we took a glass and did the thing you do where you look meaningful at each other over liquid you cannot afford alone.

Priya leaned in my door later and said, “Do you want to tell me now or later that you are in love with someone with a map,” and I said, “Later,” and she said, “Good, we will be inefficient with our time for once,” and then the afternoon did that thing it does where it lies down and refuses to be roused, and we gave up and walked down to the river and let the cold show us our edges.

When I got home there was a note pushed under my door with the fish grinning as if he had made himself a promotion. It said, I want to show you something, but not if your brain is made of lawsuits. I considered honestly whether my brain could be returned to meat in time and decided yes, with conditions. I knocked and she pulled me into a room that had had its furniture rearranged by someone who had learned the philosophy of chairs overnight. On the table, the square box of days had been opened and would not close properly because it was at capacity, and around it were sheets of paper more serious than canvas, the kind you buy when your wrists have ambitions. On one of them, in the cleanest black I have seen outside of a crow’s wing, was a diagram.

“It is a lie,” she said before I could speak. “It is also true. It is the rope as seen from above. I put the pit on paper so that if I forget and if a person asks me to be generous about my memory, I can point at it and say, Here. The pit does not move. It does not have feelings. It is geography. We do not forgive geography; we go around it or we fall in and then we tell the story. I told the tattooist they could write absence so small in the lines that no one would read it but me, but he said ink is not good at secrets, and I said that is the point.”

I stood with my hands carefully in the air above my pockets like a man in a museum who trusts his arms only when they have been assigned chairs. The drawing was both elegant and, somehow, almost shy about its own edges. The negative space in it had a shape like someone standing sideways in a doorway. It was undeniably beautiful and it was also a thing that made me angry because it made me want to be better than I was, and I do not always enjoy being given homework by art.

“May I be stupid for a minute,” I asked, and she looked at me the way a very good teacher looks at a boy who is about to be very brave in front of a room. “When you say pit, I think of the place I put all the versions of myself that were not promoted. I understand that your pit is not that. I am trying not to make it mine. I do not wish to picnic where you learned to count.”

“You may be stupid for more than a minute,” she said. “You may be stupid as a method. I will tell you when your stupidity is a fence and when it is a path. The only thing I will not have is your pretending not to see the drawing when it is on the table. Men pretend not to see drawings and it makes the world unbearable.”

“I see the drawing,” I said, and she nodded, satisfied not at my compliance but at my transparency. She put the diagram in the box on top of the day that looked like a thin sheet of bone and the lid almost shut. We stood in our two houses with our one fence and the eighth of an inch between politeness and the lack of it, and then we did not stand anymore because standing is a ceremony that has to be interrupted if it is not to become worship.

The letter to the man with the van did its work. His agent wrote back in a tone that had been curated to sound competent, and informed us that the deposit had indeed been put somewhere like a dragon sitting on a plate and that the notice would be reissued with apologies, and that obviously it had nothing to do with anything except how the world is, and would she be so good as to admit that. We sent them a paragraph about gas certificates that sounded like a lullaby if you did not speak the language, and I gave Iris a timetable that looked like an arrangement with winter. She put it on the back of a cupboard with tape that had had a life before this and saluted it each morning like it had saved hers, which is a habit I am going to adopt for the calendar above my desk.

There was a night when Mina appeared with an umbrella and a face that had argued with a bus driver and won, and she brought a parcel the size of a clementine and said, “Smell,” and we did and it smelled like green. She told me a story about a woman in her twenties who had been given a plant by a man who asked nothing in return, and how the plant had died immediately because sometimes kindness is a shock to the system. She told Iris she had found a frame in a shop that was secretly made of good wood and that she had bought it against the day when a day demanded existing twice. She told me that if we wrote to the man with the ladder in a way that made him afraid of his own conscience we would be doing him a favor. There are people who are engines in rooms, and you do not know the wattage until the light changes.

Later, after Mina left us a recipe that was more of a reminder, Iris took down a bundle of letters and put one in my hand with the care you give a child a fragile thing: do not drop it, do not run with it, do not try to eat it even if it is sweet. The paper had been folded and folded and then smoothed and then folded again the way skin folds over time regardless of whether you approve. On the front, my name in someone else’s hand, a past version of hers who wrote like a person running to catch up with herself.

“You can read that one if you want,” she said, ambiguously generous. “It does not betray anyone. It is the letter where I invented a lamp and told it it was you. Be cautious with my sixteen-year-old sense of drama. I have largely forgiven her. Mostly I am grateful to her for doing the first draft.”

I read, hungry and then careful. She wrote about the light in a shop on a wet day, and the way people’s faces behaved differently in the reflection of glass than they do in front of themselves, and about a boy whose name was mine who laughed at a joke and then took it back, and about the river when it decides to be sounded like pennies and mirrors, and about the woman who sold lemons in a bag that made everything else the lemon thought about. She wrote like someone who could not keep ink in a bottle, and if I had met her then I would have been no use to her at all. I folded it back into itself with reverent incompetence and gave it back, and the look on Iris’s face when I did that will endure longer in me than any case law I will ever cite.

The following Thursday the boy did not appear and the square was like a mouth that had forgotten a word. We stood anyway and did the respectful nothing that attendance is; the nurse with the braid nodded at us like we were the right kind of harmless, and then, just when a silence had started to think itself the only thing left, the boy came running with his case, and he did the kind of panting apology that includes the thing but also apologizes for the day. “They moved her,” he said, so quickly the words slid into each other and became objects. “Different window. I had to find the new echo.”

He looked so young then that my chest did the involuntary thing it does when you hear a body announce its age without meaning to. Iris put her hand on the case as if steadying the instrument and the boy in the same gesture, and she said, “We will learn it with you.” He blew a note and the courtyard made its best effort to be useful. The new window was where the building had decided to tuck a kindness it had not told anyone about. We stayed longer than we should and no one told us to leave, which is how the world earns a reprieve.

On the street that night, with the lights doing that pleased-with-themselves thing they do when they are the only decoration anyone can afford, the landlord’s van was out front of number 12 and the ladder was in performance. He was a man with a face like a door that tries to look like a window. He stepped down in that careful way men step down when they have been told their balance is admirable and they do not want to insult the compliment by falling. He saw me seeing him and did a small calculation and found his manners. “All right?” he said, in the dialect of men who will let you starve in their kitchens and ask if you have eaten.

“All right,” I said, which is a code for not at all. “Your agent received our letter.”

“Yes,” he said, eyes travelling past my shoulder to my window because people look at windows when they are thinking about money. “Lot of fuss. My cousin says if you live up north you can just tell people what to do and the roof agrees. But I don’t live up north and my cousin is an idiot, so we’ll do it by the book. She all right in there?” He jerked his head in the direction of Iris’s door with a theatrical casualness that made me want to nail politeness to the front of his van.

“She is all right in there,” I said. “She is better than all right. She has art on the walls.”

He made a face like a person who has just remembered a childhood injury he cannot prove. “Art,” he said, with the tone of a plumber who has discovered a skylight where there ought to have been a pipe. “Right. Tell her I won’t be unreasonable.” Then he climbed his ladder as if he'd just learned to do it that way and had been complimented on the improvement.

I told her what he had said and she laughed, not out of cruelty but out of the relief that comes when fear has to perform under supervision. “Unreasonable,” she said. “We will send him a ribbon if he manages it. We will write Thank you for being average on it in neat italics.”

We continued to be the kind of selves we were making with each other. There were mornings when she left before I did and I would find the smell of her tea in the hallway like a small echo. There were nights when I forgot to be efficient with sleep because her hair had decided to classify itself as geography and I had argued with it the way men argue with maps. The absence on her arm healed into something that seemed at home with itself, and the first time she swam after it— in a pool that had decided to be generous at an off-hour, with a lifeguard the color of brick and a sign that said NO BOMBING as if anyone had tried recently— she emerged and stood and the water made a hundred versions of the same decision, and I had the thought that if there is a God, he is suspicious of fences but he approves of towels.

Priya, vigilant and unromantic, asked me on a Monday whether I had stopped mistaking weather for plot yet and I told her I was failing honorably. She said that was acceptable as long as I continued to turn up to court with both shoes.

The trouble with clocks is that they keep their appointments even when you have been clever around them. The reissued letter arrived with the redress of mistakes attached like a ribbon. The date had moved; the intention had not. Sixty days coiled on our table; sixty days pretending to be neutral. We laid out calendars the way you lay out cutlery and gave each day a job and a number and I drew lines between them with the same steady hand I use when I escort words through a document nobody wants to read.

“We can plan so hard we forget to inhabit the plan,” Iris said, because of course she said it. “We will write, we will argue, we will ask the council to remember me like a good pupil, and we will paint the days, and we will also drink our tea while it is hot.”

“We will,” I said, which was a vow trained in a cathedral and let loose on a kitchen.

I did not know what form the interruption would take and I am embarrassed by that, because interruptions have a grammar and you can learn it if you listen in the hall for long enough. It arrived as a message from a small device in my pocket that has more status than it should and it said that my father had fallen, which is not a verb I like attached to the person who taught me to stand on a chair very early and not be foolish about it. He had fallen in a garden that used to be a proper garden and had treasured leaks weeping in ancient taps that had always done their best, and he had been found by a neighbor who kept dahlias in disciplined rows and judgments in looser ones, and he was at the place with the disinfectant and the bins and the echo. I stood very still while the room discovered how to make itself into a hallway and Iris came near me in a way that did not ask permission because some kinds of touch are not about permission but about gravity, and she said nothing and waited as if waiting was a profession she had been practicing for years.

“I have to go,” I said, and she nodded so that the nod might carry me, and Mina appeared without having been called with a scarf like a banner and a bag with the sort of things in it you only know to bring if you were a mother once and can still smell when soup is required in a different house. The street had the courtesy to be smaller while I put a coat on the wrong way and then the right way, and the bells, because they have a schedule, did not ring for me.

At the hospital, corridors bent like questions. My father sat up, which relieved me to an extent I am ashamed of, and held his mouth as if it might say things of its own accord if not supervised. He saw me and did the thing men do between other men when tenderness cannot find a place to sit, which is to insult the obvious. “You look tired,” he said, and I said, “So do you,” and then he shut his eyes because something about the arrangement of lights had decided to be too much effort and I was suddenly and completely made of patience. The nurse with the braid passed us and I had the ridiculous and unhelpful thought that the hospital had only commissioned one nurse and used her gently in all rooms like a good lamp.

He was fine, they said. It is a word that was not made for fathers. A hip bruised, not broken. A head examined and found intact and, astonishingly, a hip flask produced from a pocket with a comedy that made the doctor put his hand on the wall. I walked him home under a sky that had decided to apologise for a thing I had not heard, and in his kitchen, which is a museum of floating screws and jars with uses only he can articulate, he told me a story about his first case as a plumber, and I told him nothing that would make him afraid of me, which is a kind of kindness I wish we did not owe our parents. When I left, he stood with his hand on the edge of the door and said, too casually, “You’re okay,” and I said, too quickly, “Yes,” and then we both laughed at each other because neither of us are convincing liars.

I walked back along the Alban Way because when you are trying to put your chest into a shape people can tolerate, a path without houses is a good idea. The trumpet boy passed me at a run, case against his thigh, and I did not stop him because some urgencies are ordinary and do not require witness. When I turned onto Clarence Road, Iris was at my door, leaning with her forehead against the cold pane lightly as if listening to a rumor. She looked up and came towards me in three steps that were not dramatic and still did the necessary thing, and she put her hand on my face and held it there and taught the skin to be calm again.

“Soup,” she said, and I almost cried because I had not realized how many problems use the same solution. We went inside and the room organized itself around us politely and I told her about the fall and she told me about a painting that had failed in an interesting way and we made being alive together look like an activity that had instructions but did not need them. Afterwards, when we had done the dishes with the right sponge— do not write to me about sponges; I will not be moved— and when the street had decided that it would let us be obscure for a few hours, she said, “If I disappear for a day because the new rope tugs me, will you come find me,” and this time I said, “Yes, and I will be tedious about it,” and we both agreed that sometimes tedium is love in work clothes.

The envelope with the landlord’s second intentions continued to be itself on the cupboard door. The boy’s sister moved rooms and windows and we tracked her like saints with an app. Priya gave me a list of men worse than me and told me to stand at the end of it with dignity. Mina told me that when she left the country she loved she took photographs of the taps in the sinks of public buildings because sometimes that is how you carry water with you. The fox acquired a limp and then discarded it on a Monday like an accessory.

I would like to tell you that Chapter Six is where I learned to be easy. It is not. It is where I learned that absence is a thing you can draw and still be surprised by the hole when you step into it. It is where a letter wore a coat and rang my neighbor’s bell and made us put diagrams on the table. It is where a boy learned a new echo and where a father performed gravity and where a van decided to be civil. It is where hands learned new permissions and the kettle kept behaving even when time refused to. You would think that would be enough for a person. You would be wrong, but only by an inch, which in some rooms is all the difference between falling and staying upright.

The day the council wrote back, the envelope was the color of earnest potatoes. It sat on my mat with an authority it hadn’t quite earned and made the hall into a tiny office. I picked it up and my hand did the ridiculous tremor it reserves for documents that might change the furniture. Iris appeared the way she has learned to appear when letters arrive—she does not make a noise; she is simply there, as if summoned by the warding ink on the front. We stood with our shoulders almost touching and made the complicated decision to open it in my kitchen rather than hers, as if the kettle could confer jurisdiction.

Inside, the words behaved. They told us someone would “engage” with her “situation” and “assess her vulnerability” in a tone that made vulnerability sound like a hobby gone too far. There were bullet points that attempted kindness and a list of dates that would be our dates now whether we liked them or not. Near the bottom, there was the sentence I had been wanting and dreading: “We will require evidence.” I could have written it myself on any day in my career and hated me for the neatness of the phrase.

“I have evidence,” Iris said, sitting and laying her arm along the edge of the table with an ease that was not yet ease and not yet not. “I have a whole museum. Receipts. Letters. Photographs of gutters behaving badly. Paintings of days. Would they like a box of colors. Would they like a trumpet. Would they like my mother’s name.”

“They will want the kinds of evidence less persuasive than those,” I said, because the truth does not always help. “But we can bring both kinds and let the room decide if one can teach the other.”

She wrapped both hands around her mug and nodded like a person agreeing with a sensible song. The dressing on her arm had been gone for a week, and the ink had learned her skin and her skin had learned its ink, and sometimes my eyes forgot to flinch and sometimes they did not, and on those days I kept my hands busy with spoons. She looked at the council letter again and smiled with no teeth. “Engage,” she said. “They make engagement sound like a duel.”

“It is,” I said. “Only with clipboards.”

We started to gather proof in piles that should not have looked beautiful and did. Mina arrived with a plastic folder that had clearly been repurposed from a schoolboy some decades ago and put on the table the exact sort of biscuits people tell themselves they don’t like. “Do not be original,” she said, tapping the letter with two fingers that have signed more petitions than I will ever read. “Originality makes civil servants nervous. You will bring them the buttons they recognize and then later you will show them ribbons.”

“I have a drawer of ribbons,” Iris said, and Mina smiled like someone whose belief in her had found fresh reasons.

There were practical intrusions too, because clocks keep their promises. The letting agent, having learned the word compliance recently, discovered the word viewing. He phoned in the tone of a dentist announcing a minor procedure and asked whether “prospective tenants” might be introduced to the rooms “at convenient intervals,” by which he meant at intervals convenient to his commute. Iris handed me the phone without commentary and I became the man with the voice I keep for other men who have invoices.

“You will give twenty-four hours’ notice in writing,” I said, as if we were discussing weather. “You will propose times. You will receive refusals. You will propose different times. You will be reasonable. And you will not tell anyone she has to let people into the place where she keeps her sleep.”

There was a silence into which a smaller man might have poured apology. This man poured policy. “Of course,” he said. “We will be accommodating.” He said accommodating like a room with too much furniture. We wrote him a letter anyway, to make the law sit near us on the rug.

When the first viewing came, everything in number 12 made itself look like itself. The plant stood up straighter; the sofa decided not to be apologetic; the three turned canvases on the opposite wall remained turned, which felt like an act of mercy. Iris drew a chalk line on the hall floor in a clean arc from the skirting board to the edge of the door and looked at it with an expression so grave the chalk nearly curtsied. “Boundary,” she said. “We will be polite to them. They will not step over this.”

“You’re allowed to be unpolite,” I said, and then I ruined my own sentence with a smile.

“I like being unpolite with purpose,” she said. “Not for sport.”

The agent arrived with keys and nervousness. With him came a couple who had the careful happiness of people who had been looking for a long time and had agreed between themselves to not betray how much they wanted to be done looking. Behind them was a single man in a jacket that considered itself performance and a woman with a clipboard who wore her hair like a declaration of independence. We introduced the rooms like they were shy children. The man in the jacket walked to the mantel and fingered the jar with ointment and the jar looked up at me and said, silently, please remove him. The woman with the clipboard asked about boilers in a way I approved. The couple stood together like geography and looked at the light as if they had applications to submit to it.

Iris spoke very little. She had learned to be small without diminishing, a skill I cannot teach. When the man in the jacket opened his mouth to say something about “the vibe,” Mina, who had appeared to water the plant at the exact inconvenient moment, turned to him and said, with a smile that could butter knives, “I’m so glad you like the walls. The walls like to be treated well. They remember.”

After, when the door shut with the sigh a door makes when it has been made to work too hard, Iris and I stood within the chalk arc and not outside it. I felt in that small pale curve the full intelligence of the rope she had spoken into the skin of her arm, and a contrition I did not owe anyone presented itself anyway. She looked at my face like she was skimming a book she knows by heart and nodded, as if to say, all right then, you were paying attention.

At work, Dawson produced a file in a color that has never meant anything good. He put it on my desk like an expensive brick and said, with the benevolence of a man about to ask a favor which he does not intend ever to repay, that a partner at another firm would be grateful if we could address “informal arrangements” in “a family matter” with “discretion,” which is a cousin of secrecy that eats better. The details brought the worst out of the paper: money, yes, and property, and in the middle of it two boys who had shared a bedroom until someone left and took all the air with him. The client wanted to be reassured that the law would not punish him for how he had arranged his life after the leaving and before the paperwork caught up. I have patience up to a line. It is possible the line was painted on the floor when I wasn’t watching.

“Is there violence,” I asked, which is the first question when everything has already started moving furniture.

Dawson did a face. “Nothing actionable.”

“Actionable is a poverty of language,” I said, which is a thing Priya has taught me to say out loud even when men are wearing good coats.

Priya stole the file when Dawson left the room and put her finger under the sentence that said “exclusive occupation,” as if it were a splinter. “They want to move the children like chairs,” she said softly. “You can say no with a very pretty voice if you need to.”

I took the file home and put it on my table next to Iris’s timetable because we do not live lives where subjects can be segregated well. She looked at the top sheet and made a small noise in her throat that meant she could smell iron again. “Will you be good,” she asked, without tone, and I answered with the same absence of theatre, “I will try.”

I found myself, that week, holding pens like weapons. The fountain pen she had given me had become the metronome for my days; its nib made decisions and I followed them faithfully. On Tuesday I signed my name so many times the shape of it blurred, and I had to write it once very large on an envelope not for posting just to remind my hand there was still a person with a mouth attached to the strokes. On Wednesday, in a lunch hour that refused to sit, I went to Perpetual Ink and stood among the pins and the prints and the smell of antiseptic bravery and asked the man with the long fingers whether he had ever written on himself with ordinary ink.

“All the time,” he said, as if I had asked whether he breathed. “All the time when I was a child, and then my mother would do the thing with spit on her thumb like a magician, and now when I am trying to find the edge of a thing I use the kind that will not last. Makes room for mistakes. Makes room for the days when you want to be a different speech.”

He looked at me as if I was a map he had been paid to read and added, more kindly than he needed to, “It takes a certain type to put their own name on their skin and mean it. Most people only want pictures of who they’ve met.”

“I want a rope,” I said, surprising myself with how easily the word came. “But not the kind people see when I go to court.”

He nodded, unsurprised. “Then draw it more often than you need. In pen. In pencil. Not because you don’t commit—but because you practice obedience to yourself.”

I went back to the office and drew a line on the inside of my left wrist with the fountain pen, thin as a vein, and washed it off before the meeting with Dawson. The faint ghost of it stayed as if ink had opinions. Priya saw it and did not ask me a question; she raised a single eyebrow in that very competent way she has and moved a file from my left to my right in case I forgot which hand had weather.

My father phoned me on a Thursday, which is a day he considers vulgar for telephones. He sounded like kettle steam. The fall had turned his balance into something he had to argue with in small rooms, and he hated arguing with anything that did not have a washer to fix. “Your mother used to say I fell up,” he said, without preamble. “This time I fell down. We must cover all directions so as not to show favoritism.”

“I’ll come up this weekend,” I said, because sometimes obedience is not a wound.

He made a skeptical noise about my car, which is a reasonable noise to make if you have ever seen my car, and told me a story about an apprentice who had decided to keep parts in his pocket and how it went very badly for the sink. He did not ask about Iris. He will ask about Iris when he believes he will outlive the answer. I told him anyway, which is a small rebellion. I told him she made boxes of days and that her arm had learned a new alphabet and that she is a person who knows where the pit is. He grunted, which is how he metabolizes information that wants to live in his stomach instead of in his mouth, and said, “Don’t be made a fool of,” which is his way of saying be brave. I told him I would try to compromise between those two.

That night, the boy did not play because the sister had been taken to a room without windows and the nurse with the braid had asked us both, in the kindest voice I have ever heard in a corridor, to be ordinary somewhere else. Iris took me to the river which is where she takes me when she wants my mouth to be quiet. The water had decided to be opaque about everything. It wore the sky like a second story and did not regret it. She stood very still as if being in one place long enough could persuade the world to tell the truth, and I thought suddenly, and quite without permissions, that there will be a morning when she will live in another house that is not this one and I will make a cup of tea in my kitchen which will be my kitchen and maybe also not, and I will feel the shape of her not-here and it will be a furniture in the room.

“Don’t do that,” she said, as if I had said any of it aloud.

“What,” I asked, genuinely not sure which part of me had been impolite.

“Make the future the villain,” she said. “The future is already sorry. It doesn’t need you piling on.”

We stood until our knees accused us, and then we walked through streets that had decided to let their lights be kindly instead of clever. In the window of the charity shop, the SPLENDID piano had gathered two stools, perhaps by sympathy. The shop had put a sign on it that said TRY ME in a hand that refused to be humiliated by chalk. A child with a hat too large for her head sat and hammered middle C like a telegram and the woman beside her said, with a patience I want to bottle, “You can try other letters. They do exist.”

There was a morning—I do not know which one; it exists outside calendar—in which Iris and Mina made soup with a seriousness that caused the onions to obey. I was allowed to slice bread, which is a task I can be trusted with when watched. They spoke, these two and their long history, about ingredients as if listing virtues. Thyme, Mina said, is faithfulness without aggression. Bay is patience with form. Lentils are a union. They did not talk about men and I was the better for it. When we ate, Iris’s sleeve slipped and her skin did that gleam it does when recently in contact with soap and rubbing, and I watched myself not look away. I watched myself not force looking. Later, washing dishes, she pressed the heel of her hand into my lower back without thought, as if her body had learned that I was furniture that did not mind its job, and I had to go into another room for a minute and tell my chest it could stop pretending to be a cathedral.

We went to the council together, which is a sentence you do not get to say unless certain clocks have refused to be charmed. The building was exactly itself, a municipal agreement between beige and industriousness. Outside, the cigarette smoke of the worried and the routine made a slogan of the air. Inside, the woman who saw us first had a cardigan with moral opinions. She took Iris’s name and spelled it three different ways until the name gave up and spelled itself. Then she said, with bureaucratic dignity, “Take a seat,” and we tried without grimacing the blue plastic seats that have been designed to correct posture in seven nations.

The officer who came to fetch us had hair like a promise she had kept a long time ago. She led us into a room that had forgotten its first purpose and asked Iris questions in a voice that made my own voice take its shoes off. Iris answered as if she were painting a day: not the picture of a thing, but the weather of it. She told the truth without stage directions. When asked for evidence, she laid her papers on the table like a dinner service she would let anyone eat from and also protect with her life. The officer took notes in handwriting that made me believe in legibility. When we showed her the defects in the notice, she did not perform delight or disdain; she said, “That will help,” and tilted the page so the fluorescent light didn’t hum over it.

Are you at risk, she asked then, the most serious question in the repertoire. Iris looked at her arm and not at her face and said, “Not from anyone who is in the room,” and the officer did a thing I will remember—a small nod that conceded a battlefield she had not been allowed to enter and respected anyway. She gave us dates and a list of acronyms that had learned to live together and pressed a card into Iris’s hand as if cards could be medicine. When we stood, she said, to Iris, gently, “Tell us if anyone tries to make you move your own rope,” and Iris said, “I will tell you and I will be very boring about it,” and I put the sentence in my pocket to keep.

Outside, the fox crossed the car park in daylight, his indecency made daylight-proof. He looked like he had taken a class in urban policy and found it beneath him. We watched him go with a fond contempt I recommend.

The partner at the other firm called me that afternoon, his voice prepped to be collegiate. He wanted a letter that would, as he put it, “calm the waters,” and his waters were two boys who had a mother in one house and a father in another and an arrangement that flattered the adult timetable and insulted the children’s. I told him I would write what the facts would bear and he said the phrase “agreed narrative,” and I said “best interests,” and we both said the word “amicable” with sincerity and fully aware of its limits. When I put the phone down, Priya rolled her chair into my doorway and said, “I am so tired of people wanting affection to be measurable,” and I said, “Me too,” and then, because she is not wrong about ritual, we went to buy very bad coffee.

That evening Iris knocked and did not wait for me to say come in, which is not rudeness in our dialect. She stood in the hall and lifted her sleeve and I braced and did not need to be braced because there was nothing new to be seen except my own failure to be frightened. “It has stopped being a guest,” she said, in that tone of wonder people have when they realize the cat has decided the house belongs to it. “I thought I should tell you. It will take its shoes off without being asked now. If you want to look, look because you like the room, not because you’re checking for burglars.”

I looked. The lines had softened in the way a line softens when it becomes a fact. The negative space did its calm work. I realized that what had scared me at the beginning was not the ink but the announcement of someone else’s decision, and I liked myself for disliking myself, which is a curious but useful position from which to make changes. “I like the room,” I said, and her face did a very small shift that loosened the skin over her cheekbones and allowed the girl who wrote letters to boys she hadn’t met to peek out and then politely retire.

She told me then about her father, not a full story, but a shelf. He had written to her when she was twenty with a letter that contained more suggestions than salutations. He had told her to “present better,” which is something men say to women when they are afraid of mirrors, and she had not spoken to him for a year and it had been both a relief and a sickness. The tattoo, she said, was not about him because he is not a pit, he is a man, and men do not get to be pits just because they are deep and loud. But the rope, she said, is about the habit of agreeing with suggestions. “When I put my arm down on a table now,” she said, “I’m putting down a map where someone else might have set a meal. It helps me remember not to eat when I’m not hungry.”

We fell into the kind of quiet that is not a pause but a plan. She sat on my floor and drew lines on a napkin that became leaves that became a staircase that became nothing you could name without sounding like you had made the world on a Thursday. I wrote in my notebook in the untidy way I do when the pen wants to be quick. In between those activities we spoke about the trumpet boy’s absence as if he had gone to fetch a word and would be back with it soon. We made the tea behave and then asked it to forgive us for letting it drift. We watched a program where people with aprons made cakes the size of insults and we were unkind about one of the judges and instantly remorseful, and that is, I think, the proper ratio of vice to correction.

On Saturday I went to my father’s. The train practiced being late and then was late properly. The sky decided to do all its weathers in one small rectangle. My father opened the door with a dignity that had been ironed and un-ironed several times. He had put the kettle on the moment he heard my feet and it made the kitchen seem good-mannered. He showed me the bruise on his hip with an abruptness I have learned is his version of intimacy, and it was livid and purposeful, like a country he did not intend to stay in. His sink, known to me since childhood as the place where screws propose to nuts, stared at me as if to say we were both not behaving like equipment today.

We quarrelled gently in the way people do when the quarrel is an old house they have both lived in and neither want to pay council tax on anymore. He told me to move the screwdriver I had moved and I told him his lightbulbs were a hazard and he told me my hair was falling out and I told him his temper was not a tool and then we laughed and ate sandwiches that had remembered to be simple. When I left, he did a thing I did not expect: he pressed a small, surprisingly heavy parcel into my hand wrapped in paper that had once belonged to Christmas. “Your mother kept this,” he said, staring over my shoulder at the coats. “She told me not to give it to you until you were likely to do something unsensible with it and then take responsibility. She said I wouldn’t know when that was, so I suppose you’ll have to tell me if I’ve got it wrong.”

On the train I opened it because I am incapable of waiting when an object announces it has a story. It was a round brass pocket watch, scarred, weighty, its back engraved with a pattern that looked like frost learning to be geometry. Inside, where the mechanism’s heart should tick, there was a small note in my mother’s hand that said, In case you ever need to slow the afternoon. I held it and the train took a corner and in the window I saw the long, ridiculous face I have always had and the very specific angle at which it softens when presented with a kindness I do not deserve. I brought the watch to Iris and she held it like a bird and then put it to her ear and said, “It is not working,” and then, “No, I am wrong, it is working in a different room.”

We took it to a man near the market who fixes time for a living. His shop was a museum of measurement. He spoke very little and listened to the watch and then to my name and then to my mother’s handwriting, because some trades insist on being fed with stories. “It is delicate,” he said, which was his way of saying, you will have to live with how it behaves. He said he would coax it and perhaps it would do us the kindness of remembering its old job. We left it there and walked away with a piece of paper that promised nothing more than a possible reunion.

The trumpet boy returned that week with a borrowed instrument and a face that had learned the word wait. The sister had moved to a room with a garden no one is allowed in. He played in the square and the hospital pretended not to notice and the bins were very quiet. Iris stood with her sleeve down and her hands in her pocket and her mouth made a shape I hadn’t seen on it yet, a shape that said I am older in this second than I was when I woke. When he finished, he did not look at us. He packed the trumpet like an apology and then, after the case had closed, turned and said, “Her name is Ruth,” and then left the name with us as if it were a parcel we were entrusted with on the understanding that we would not open it unless we were asked.

The landlord’s agent wrote to offer us a compromise that was not a compromise but a calendar with a red square around the day he would prefer to have keys in his hand. We wrote back with politeness that had teeth. Priya took my draft and inserted three phrases that would make a county court judge feel as if he were being done the favor of remembering a precedent, and reminded the man that people are not keys and time is not his to own. Mina arrived with a coat that had outlived two governments and said, “We are going to look at a place,” and Iris said, “We are not going to look at a place without Bret,” and Mina said, “Bret is invited if he can keep his mouth from telling the room that it is a room,” and I said, “I will write a letter to my mouth.”

The place was on a road that had mislaid its notion of itself. It had balconies too small for chairs and windows too large for secrets. The agent used the word “airy” as if he had personally inflated it. The kitchen admitted silently to once being something else. In the bedroom, the light had learned how to get around corners. Iris walked through it with her hands behind her back like a person observing a painting she does not need to buy to understand. She stood on the patch of floor where the boards have given up and jumped once with both feet like a child in a puddle, then looked at me to see if I would scold. I did not. Mina, at the window, said, “It is enough,” which is the most dangerous sentence a human being can say.

Outside, Iris said, “If this is the place, I will have to teach the walls new words,” and I said, selfishly and somehow correctly, “Not yet,” and she said, “Not yet,” in a tone that made me brave again for a few hours.

On an ordinary night in the ordinary week after that, I woke at the hour all kitchens make their private noises. The house felt like a person running a hand over their hair. I went downstairs and lit one of the three candles she had given me months ago, and the light did that small discipline thing I have learned is not to be taken for granted. I took my pen and drew a rope on my wrist and did not wash it off until morning. In the quiet you tell yourself you are keeping watch over the person you intend to be, and sometimes that person turns up and sits with you and steals your tea and asks you to be less ridiculous and you agree and then fail and then agree again.

I don’t know how long chapter eight is supposed to be. In my life, chapters have never ended exactly where I would like them to. They end because a bus arrives or a letter does not or a person with a braid tells you to be ordinary elsewhere. They end because you fall asleep before you finish a paragraph and, in the morning, you discover the paragraph was kinder without you. There is a day coming—and I say this not with dread but with the relief of being allowed to admit it—when the rope we have drawn on paper and skin will be asked to hold. There is a court date printed now on one of our calendars with a sensible font. There is a boy who will teach a new window to echo. There is a watch that is either remembering or refusing. There is a father who will tell me a story about a pipe as a way of not saying he missed me. There is a woman I love who has taught me where the floor gives way and shown me how to step and permitted me to put my hand on the small of her back in the four seconds between a door and a room. If I am being dramatic, it is only because time keeps laying itself gently on brick and slate, and I keep wanting to know whether the bend of it is a kindness or a test. I have learned, at least, to light the candle and let it behave. I have learned to write we as a verb. I am learning not to move the rope. And on Thursdays, when the trumpet finds the square and the boy lifts his chin, I stand in the place where the sound will hit and I let it.

The watchmaker rang in the morning when the world was trying on ash-grey and kept it, and said, in a voice that had been lifted and put down on velvet many times, that he had persuaded the mechanism to remember itself for stretches of time in the afternoon if handled with respect. He spoke of springs like small laws and cautioned me against winding as if I wanted something. When I collected it, the shop smelled of old arithmetic and lemon oil, and he laid the watch on a square of felt as if he were placing a quiet animal back into its field. On the walk home I kept opening it, not because I mistrusted its face, but because watching the seconds heave themselves forward in a disciplined way felt like a kindness I had not earned. I put it in Iris’s palm and she closed her fingers around it as if she was saving a moth from our stupidity, and we held it to our ears, two schoolchildren with a contraband sea shell, listening for the hour that might slow if we asked nicely.

The letter from the council that said engage and assess was followed by another with a list that might as well have been titled How To Be Proved. We gathered the things rooms shed: receipts like small confessions, photographs that showed gutters when sunshine had expected to be the subject, the tenancy agreement with its festivals of small print, and a page Mina had found in a cupboard that confirmed the gas certificate had taken a sabbatical during a year when people were being alive anyway. Priya came by in her lunch break under the pretense of borrowing a book she had already read and put a paperclip in the correct place with a gentleness that made the clip feel forgiven. We did not feel like we were winning or losing; we felt like people carrying a pane of glass between us, and occasionally a gust made it urgent that we keep it level.

The agent discovered the word block-viewing and wanted to show five strangers how the light behaves in Iris’s front room all at once on a Tuesday. I wrote a sentence that placed civility on the floor like a rug and invited him to step onto it carefully, and he wrote back with the particular version of yes that is also a sigh. When they came, the chalk arc on the hall floor improved everyone’s posture. The couple who held each other's curiosity almost as well as each other's hands asked if foxes come in the garden, and Iris said, “They leave us alone if we leave them their routes,” and the woman with a fringe made of deliberation said, “I grew up where hedgehogs were a rumor,” and looked at the fence as if it might confess. The man in the ambitious jacket touched the spines of Iris’s books with the pads of two fingers and pretended not to read titles. Mina watered the plant slowly and made eye contact with the woman from the agent’s office in a way that persuaded her to put the clipboard down and become human for three minutes.

On a Wednesday that was so precisely itself the church bells could have used it as a toner, Dawson brought me a family case with the email equivalent of a flourish. The line he underlined twice was “unequal shares of holiday time,” which is a domestic way of saying someone is smoothing their own pillow with the argument that a child should not mind the crease. I said the phrases best interests and reasonable arrangements in a tone that had straps, and spoke to a solicitor across town who hated the word contact but was prepared to use it if it got us all to tea. Afterwards, Priya leaned in my doorway and told me that the word amicable is a place two people can live if they don’t mind the windows being painted shut, and I wrote that down, and later, in my notebook at home, I wrote Iris’s name above it because I am running an experiment on how words behave when they are placed next to each other without explicit instructions.

The boy with the trumpet came on a Thursday with a determination that made the courtyard straighten its bin lids. The nurse with the braid was in a different hallway but had clearly told the others what kind of trouble we were, because the guard whose shoes know the length of every passage in that building nodded at us like we were volunteers who had quietly turned up again. He played not scales but a tune so ordinary it made the buildings remember their childhoods, something from a radio in someone’s kitchen, long ago, that had told people who were cooking to be patient. When he finished, he pressed his fist against the closed bell like he did not trust his mouth. Later, in the square near the market where older men feed small birds with old bread and political opinions, he told us Ruth had been permitted to sit in a chair in a room with plants for twenty minutes. Iris made the noise she makes when art and medicine shake hands, and I felt the relief you feel when you find a word you had lost down the back of the day.

The court date to argue with a piece of paper about whether it was allowed to rearrange the furniture arrived in sensible type on a sheet that made us both drink water. We photocopied things that had never wanted to be photocopied and put them into a folder that had learned the stoop of heavy. The morning of, I put on a suit that likes to think well of itself and Iris put on a jumper the color of the inside of a pear and we walked down Holywell Hill together as if it were a corridor with a patient at the end. In the waiting area I opened the watch, and I swear the second hand did an unshowy thing with time that made my ribcage less of a drum. Iris traced the edge of the folder with one fingertip in a loop that repeated and repeated until the loop itself seemed to calm. We were two people trying not to hate furniture, and I say that because rooms like those require such effort to forgive.

The judge was the exact tiredness of a man who has already eaten half of everyone’s lunch. He listened, which is rarer in those rooms than people suppose. The landlord’s representative had a tie with ambition and a file with the look of a script that had been through too many table reads. We spoke about the gas certificate and its gap, about the deposit which had been placed in the place it should have been placed into but only after the date it should have been placed, about the letter that had learned words but not the right order. When I said “compliance is not an attitude; it is a sequence,” the judge’s mouth shifted by a molecule and I took it as encouragement. Iris, when asked to confirm her name and address, said both as if introducing a painting to a room with poor lighting, and when the representative for the other side tried to say she had been obstructive about viewings she said, very quietly, “I have been careful with my house while it is still my house,” and I watched the sentence take its shoes off and sit in the judge’s good ear.

We did not win a flag; this is not that kind of book. We won time. The notice was pronounced defective in the tidy way that men say a pipe is not this pipe but perhaps the correct pipe will arrive later. The judge looked down his long bright road of cases and told the room what would happen when it happened, and the clerk in the corner typed a poem in a language that only printers read. Outside, the boy with the trumpet was not there because this was midday and not a Thursday, but the air behaved itself as if someone had just finished practicing. Mina met us on the steps because there is a clock in her that is not on anyone’s wall and pressed into Iris’s hand a small wrapped sweet that turned out to be parma violet because she enjoys watching modern people be confused by old sugar. We stood for a foolish minute and did not go anywhere, and then we went to a cafe where the coffee disappoints the way certain relatives do, reliably and in a tone of voice that insists you enjoy the tradition.

That evening we did something I had been putting off and did not know I had been putting off: we went to the late service on Ash Wednesday because I had never learned to be smeared by strangers and still be myself. The cathedral had the intentioned hush of a library at closing, and the sound of people deciding whether to kneel made a music all its own. The words about dust pressed a gentle hand on the brassy parts of my chest. A woman with a face that had become wiser ahead of schedule put thumb to forehead after forehead and drew commas. When she put the black on mine she did not press and she did not apologize. “Remember,” she said, and I did not need the object of the sentence named. Iris came behind me and received her own mark, and the charcoal line on her skin almost shook hands with the charcoal line on her skin, and the part of me that has never believed in coincidence laid down its coat and said, For tonight I will be simple.

Afterwards we bought chips and ate them in paper like a sacrament that admits it is salt and grease and still dares to propose meaning. The ash stayed on our foreheads and no one on Clarence Road told on us to their gods or ours. Iris wiped hers at her door not because she was ashamed but because she wanted to see what she looked like neither marked nor unmarked. We kissed in the lee of the porch and some of the ash transferred to my cheek, and she laughed into my mouth in a low, surprised way that made me want to pay rent on the moment. When I went home I saw my face in the dark glass of my back door and the smudge there made me feel more legible.

The next day the watch stopped briefly at ten-past-three and began again at ten-past-three, and I cannot explain that any better than I can explain foxes. The fox limped again and then did not limp later, as if a second animal had borrowed his body. At work, Dawson told a story about a golf charity and used the word philanthropic with the same mouth that had asked me the previous morning to make theft sound like weather. Priya brought me a sandwich and a verdict on a new barrister who spoke like a door closing and advised we keep him away from delicate women and any men with mothers. I wrote a letter to a court about two boys whose holidays were being divided like a pie by people who had forgotten that children are not slices, and I tried to be rude on their behalf without swearing.

I went into Perpetual Ink because the door was open and the smell of clean was argumentative. The man with the long fingers had not been reissued in the night as a different man; he lifted his chin in a way that said we had moved on from guessing games. I showed him my wrist with the faint ghost of yesterday’s drawn line, and he nodded the way men nod at engines. “Practice is half of permanence,” he said, and I told him about my mother’s watch and he told me about a sailor who had asked for a lighthouse so small no one could see it but him, and how you cannot rely on ink to be invisible but you can rely on skin to be stubborn. I did not book anything. I did not not book anything. He told me to rub olive oil into the place where the pen leaves its apology, and I said I would and did not lie.

My father came down to St Albans on a Saturday wearing the coat he wears when he wants strangers to consider him a man of good sense. He pretended his hip was not a man he was on speaking terms with now and asked to see the cathedral because he refuses to be outdone by my life. We stood under the nave and he cleared his throat at a particular piece of stonework with approval, which is my father’s highest compliment for any object not from his trade. He did not mention the ash but he looked at me with the thin amusement of a person who has learned that his son will put marks on himself from time to time as if inviting a conversation with the air. I took him to Iris’s because he is a man who will better understand art if the kettle is in the room with it, and he did the decent thing which is to make no comments for five minutes. When he did speak, he said, to Iris, “You’re handy,” and there is a scraping, profound respect in his voice when he names someone thus which sounds like mildness to those who don’t know the register. She said, “I am when watched,” and he said, “Everyone is better with a witness,” and I felt the floor push my feet back up in case I forgot how.

They made soup without performance and he washed up without being invited because that is his profession in rooms where he does not know where anything else goes. He did not refer to the rope or the ink but his eyes knew not to ask, and Iris took her sleeve down without being instructed. When he left he shook her hand as if handing something over, and in the hall he said into his collar, “She’ll do,” and I said, “For me or for you,” and he said, “What difference do you think there is,” and I made a noise that could serve for affection or murder depending on who transcribes it.

The landlord’s man discovered a new tone on the telephone that I can only call technically conciliatory and asked whether the 10 a.m. slot on the Wednesday two weeks hence would be agreeable for a further viewing of the rooms, and I said no in a way that made him consider that other people might have mornings. The couple came back anyway at a different hour because they had asked very politely and because they had the respect for chalk that is the gateway drug to other good habits. They stood in the yet-room and said they did not know if they were allowed to love the light when it belonged to someone else. Iris said, “You can practice loving without claiming,” and the man’s face twitched in a way that indicated a wound and a ready bandage. Mina turned the plant a quarter turn because plants like to have their memories rearranged from time to time.

On the day that wanted to be spring and then lost its nerve, the nurse with the braid came out into the square and told us that Ruth had smiled at the boy in a way that made the boy’s knees briefly forget which bend they prefer. She told him, very firmly, that he was doing a good job of letting the sound do the talking, and told us, with the same authority, that we were doing a good job of letting him. Iris folded the information into her voice and said the word Ruth as if she was wrapping her in paper that tissue knows how to be. We walked to the park and found the bench that never stops being damp and sat anyway because our trousers needed to learn. The river kept being practical. A dog found a stick and then discovered the holy truth that if you carry a stick you have a job, and its owner, who had the air of someone who had retired from something that should not be retired from, told the dog that this was enough for one morning.

The watch behaved at four, so we sat very still at four and made that into a superstition on purpose. Iris painted one of her square days with a color that was nearly not a color at all, a thin obedient wash laid over a layer that had been adventurous earlier. She annotated it with the time she felt the afternoon lean and wrote, in her precise plain hand that is sometimes braver than mine, Bret’s mother’s watch remembered. I wrote in my notebook without tearing the page that day, which feels like a lesson I should have learned years ago and was not offered the correct teacher.

We were not saints or lawyers in our own house every hour. There were mornings when the legal file sat under a bowl of apples and silently judged my domestic ambitions, and evenings when Iris turned a painting to the wall and then turned it back because the wall had not learned its lines yet. There were two arguments, one about the word moving, during which I performed semantics and she let me finish and then said, “We are both moving even when no one asks us to,” and one about the boy’s mother, whom I had judged for being late to the square without knowing whether she lives with a clock that is cruel. We forgave ourselves these indulgences by doing the boring thing immediately afterwards, which is to tell the truth to the part of ourselves that was flourishing melodrama for its own sake, and then we magneted our apologies to the fridge with the lemon from Arundel because committing them to metal made them more obedient.

In the middle of the month the council sent a woman with a lanyard and soft shoes to look at walls. She had a kindness that felt union-negotiated and made both of us sit up straighter than necessary. She measured the rooms with a laser that made a red dot skitter, and the fox watched through the window like a critic whose review we would pretend not to read. She looked at the letter from the landlord and at the timetable and at the list we had written in our own ink entitled Things We Have Already Tried, and then she looked at Iris’s face like it was evidence and at my posture like I had been practicing being useful, and she said, with the finality of a recipe, “We’ll be in touch,” and I believed her not because of the words but because of the angle of her shoulders when she stood.

At work a memo did its usual suspicion of daylight and instructed us to remind clients of the limitations of email, as if anyone had ever mistaken a chain for a river. I wrote a letter in handwriting on paper to a man who wanted his former wife to sign a document that had been drafted for the purpose of removing guilt from the story, and I put the letter in a postbox with a red mouth like a declaration and felt like I had done something medieval and potentially effective. Priya told me that if I started wearing tweed she would resign her friendship and then bought me an orange because she had noticed I had been living on the kind of lunches that make a person nervous about doors.

There was a Sunday we tried on a new church for curiosity and then ran away to the river because the sermon had more rules than weather. There was a Monday I went to my father’s again and found him making an omelette with the confidence of a man who has never had an omelette judge him. He told me a story about my mother’s handwriting that began at a shop counter and ended in a pocket and was, I think, about trying to keep a person near using the smallest objects available. He held the watch to his ear and said, “It sounds tired,” and I said, “It has been asked to do a magnificent amount with kindness,” and he said, “So have we,” and if you hear more romance in that exchange than two men intended, perhaps you are not wrong.

On a wet morning that had rain with a moral agenda, the landlord’s agent called to ask if the viewing could be “bumped” because a prospective tenant had a train that did not like him, and we said yes with the absentminded mercy of people who had given up counting how many times the same shoe had been placed on the same foot. Iris drew a chalk arc you could not see in wet hall light and we stood inside it anyway, habit asserting itself as an ethics. When they eventually came, the couple did not, and in their place was a man with a notebook who wrote measurements as if he were designing a coffin. He wanted to know if the walls were load-bearing and I told him no wall bears anything without being asked too often, and he smiled with his teeth and said that was not his experience. Mina arrived at the exact moment he attempted to touch the turned canvases and said, in a way that made him reconsider his day, “Those are thinking,” and he left shortly after because sometimes leaving is the correct instinct.

If you ask me what Chapter Ten is for, I will answer despite having learned that purpose hates company. It is the chapter where the watch remembers and fails and remembers again and we let that be a model. It is where the law makes a sound like a small dog turning around on a rug and lies down. It is where Iris’s rope stays steady and I draw a line on my wrist and become less ashamed of washing it off in the morning in case I have a meeting. It is the chapter where a judge gives you time and you do not spend it like a fool. It is the month of ash and soup and a child who hammers middle C until the piano questions its career. It is where I stand in a square and let a boy teach me how to be present without being useful. It is where I introduce my father to my life and nobody dies in the course of the introduction and that is not nothing. It is where the council lady says We’ll be in touch and I believe her because sometimes a sentence carries its own references in its pocket.

On a Thursday we did not expect to be different, the trumpet boy came, and stood without putting the case down, and said, “They let me play by her bed,” and he smiled with his whole face for the first time since we met him and made a noise that was not a note and not a laugh and not a cry and meant all three. Iris reached for my wrist, not the watch one, and I let her hold it as if I belonged to the idea of not making a movement that would scare a happiness away. We stood there while he told us, in the simple order of a sixteen-year-old who has run out of adjectives, about a nurse who held a door open, and a doctor who did not say no, and a woman whose mouth did the thing mouths do when they try to find a corner, and how he had played a stupid tune from the radio and it had made the air feel like a person. We did not tell him that he had saved a day because he knew it already in the same way he will not know it for years.

At night, when the street decided to be a throat and clear itself politely, Iris drew me on her box of colors in the space that does not admit paper and I did not ask to see because I have learned to enjoy believing in things without receipts. I wound the watch with my gentlest left hand and the hand moved because it had agreed to be moved. I lit a candle and then blew it out because tonight the dark was doing a better job. We lay on the floor because the floor forgives clumsy, and when she lifted her sleeve to adjust nothing in particular I looked and liked the room and did not inventory my own fear and did not write it down. We drifted into a sleep that had corrections pencilled in the margins and left them there for morning, and the fox did his appointments like a civil servant, and somewhere a judge finished his cheese and went to bed. In the middle of the night, I woke and the watch was ticking in the other room, and for once I did not get up to check that it was not ticking without us.
